Stick it to the man--the Clear Channel man--by seeing a show at Bottom of the Hill.  Believe what the masses are saying about this Potrero Hill club.  Go there now.

Located at the bottom of San Francisco's Potrero Hill, the Bottom of the Hill is a nice hidden gem of a place to see a concert. The interior looks like an old salsa club and it is a rustic place to watch bands that are just making it or great bands past their primeI saw Creeper Lagoon and Earlimart perform here. Both great alternative bands that sound similar to The Breeders, Elliott Smith, and Third Eye Blind.If you've heard of the great Oxford band Ride, their former lead singer performed here recently and if you've heard of the Great North Carolina pop punk band Archers of Loaf, the band's lead singer who is in another band now, performed here.It's a nice hole in the wall and usually, the shows do not sell out here. It's not the Fillmore or the Warfield theatre, where the big gigs are, but it is still well worth going to if you want to see some up and coming Californian and some National and International bands to perform.There is a very good bar and grill place to eat dinner, a block away, called the Yankee Doodle Dandy.

Cramped, sweaty, awesome venue to see live music. One of the best shows of my life (GUITAR WOLF) took place here. I couldn't choose a better place to be bashed in the face with a Japanese man's guitar. I also have fond memories of going to the Sunday afternoon bbq's here back in the day. Great smoking patio/pool table in the back for mingling.

Saw Alias and Tarsier there last night.  Very cool venue that provided for an intimate and great sounding show.  The place has a really grungy yet charming feel to it.  The bartender was also really nice.

By far the best venue in the city. Anybody from wildly sucessful artists to impoverished, struggling songwriters perform here. The club is tiny and intimate so you can somehow always manage to push your way through the sweaty, drunk crowd to the front row. You can get close enough to practically straddle the amps...or straddle your favorite artist. I saw Her Space Holiday here, and during the opening acts, the singer was watching the music, along with everyone else in the club, instead of pretentiously hanging backstage. It's the same way with all the artists who play here. The dim, musky club atmosphere mixed with the perfect amount of sketchiness from the surrounding neighborhood seems to really bring out the best in the bands who play here. And to top it all off, they allow you in and out privileges for smoke breaks.

It is a little cramped (I'd say "intimate" if I were a real estate agent), and it sucks to be caught behind one of those pillars, preventing you from being able to see the band, but Bottom of the Hill is still one of the best places to see a show in the city.  The booking people are doing something right.  I was once headbutted on stage by Wesley Willis here.  Awesome!Warning: it is always unbelievably loud here.  This place could make John Denver sound like Metallica.  Bring earplugs or buy some at the bar for 50 cents.

Tiny, cramped, awesome little place to check out all manner of awesome indie bands. Even if there isn't enough room to dance, there's always enough room to rock out.Convenient as well -- close to freeways and tons of street parking. Good for those of us who aren't cool enough to actually live in the city.

I like the bands that play at Bottom of the Hill. I like the crowd. I like the booze. I like the area. but i just don't like the actual venue. It's a bit cramped, and stuffy. The sound is usually a bit off. and I can't quite get over the fact that the stage is not in the center.
 I know, it's shallow of me.

Bottom line...if youve ever been lucky enough to see one of your favorite bands - before they broke - at BOTH, I think youll agree with me...this is, hands down, the best concert venue in SF...Only drawback...getting a cab after a show...BLOWS!

I've seen quite a few bands play here and I always manage to enjoy myself as well as the music. I like sitting on the shelf on the right. Gives me a good view of all the drunken bastards ruining the lyrics. Good times.

I will quote Nicolet K.:
 'They pack the fans into this venue as tightly as David Hasselhoff's speedo... And I wouldn't know first hand, but it probably gets as sweaty and humid as David Hasselhoff's speedo as well.'
 I couldn't have said it better myself.

Boy, SF music venues sure like to pack 'em in. I was here last night for the Art Brut show. It was uncomfortably packed. Reasonably priced beers, but the sound system was pretty awful, our ears were bleeding by the encore. and BEWARE the show was 18 AND OVER! You can imagine the effects of this horrible management decision. Slam dancing??? Seriously??? Oh lord. Lots of parking, that's a rare and wonderful thing. Oh, and the opening act stripped down, pulled out smoked sausages, teared them open with their teeth and ate them. Lovely.
hands down the best live music venue in sf.  great bands, great vibe, outdoor area, tasty food.
my favorite small club in sf with a constant line-up of great indie bands.  see 'em here first before they get big.
small but not cramped, loud but not bleeding ears.
always a fun time even if i don't particularly like the band...there's always the smoking patio...back when i used to smoke...[sigh]

I love this place.  I used to manage a punk rock band when I lived in Los Angeles and this was the place they always wanted to play in the Bay Area.  Now that I live here I know why.  I have to agree with Michael E. it looks just like Pee Wee Herman's rock venue, but that is what gives it that personal touch.  You can cut lose and not worry about being judged or worse, being kicked out.  If you ever want to see a good rock show, this is the place to be.  I am going to be there this Monday for Presidents Day.  There is going to be three amazing, local, unsigned rock bands playing there.  I hope to see some Yelpers there!
Evan Dando and I had a 'moment' during his show at Bottom of the Hill. I thank the intimate venue and my memory of every Lemonheads lyric ever written - it was unforgettable.

A venerable San Francisco concert institution, often showcasing bands before they make a crack at bigtime.  Oftentimes you get to experience not one but up to three or more bands in a given night.  What a perfect way to not only see your favorite headliner but to get to see similar music and open up your horizons to other great music.  If you are a smoker, the outdoor patio is a great place to mingle with friends, hipsters, scenesters and even the bands as they make their way back from a performance.  My favorite aspect of the bar -- one of the few locations that you can order both a Guinness and a Strongbow.  Concert + friends + new people + Strongbow = great night.  I always look forward to a show there, only downside is transpo can be a bit sketchy given the remote locale.

From what I remember, this seems like a pretty good venue. I wasn't overly excited to be attending a pop-rock concert, but I was suitably pacified by a lot of beer. Good beer, at that. This is a smallish place and therefore you can get 'up close and personal' with the bands. Or you can stand sidestage and drunkenly heckle them, which is what I did. And when you get tired of that, you can migrate towards the back and play pool or air hockey. There are also several soft and cushy benches near the pool table, which come in handy when you are no longer able to stand upright...Oh, hi mom!Beware of the hipsters. If you are one of those disgruntled people who has an irrational dislike towards white-belt wearing youngsters, stay away from Bottom of the Hill or you will become even more disgruntled.

Bottom of the Hill varies quite a bit. I've seen some great shows here when the crowd is small and the band has had proper time to set up. I've also seen shows that have made me move all the way to the back of the room because there are waaaaaaaaaay too many people and someone set the levels to jet-engine-loud.I always manage to get lost on my way to Bottom of the Hill though. It really is in the middle of nowhere and public transit gets you just far enough away to get you lost.

We drove along some parking lot into what looks like a factory or warehouse neighborhood looking for this place.  As soon as we saw it, everyone in the car gave a collective, "oooohhhhh."  Yeah.  It actually is a very humble place where you can find one of the most interesting groups of people; young and old, goth, punk, scenester, emo, blah blah blah.  But we saw this band called the Groovy Ghoulies or something like that and they were a lot of fun.  The atmosphere was a-ok.  Lots of piercings and tats, but a step back into the early 80's.  I think we agreed that we'd go back there.

OK.  So the sound system sometimes is off, the noise from people chattering by the entrance can be deafening, it can be unbelievably cramped when a show is sold out, festivities may end at 1 or 2 in the morning (which ain't necessarily a bad thing).  For all of its shortcomings (I'm sure people can and will drum up more), there isn't a better place to see a show in SF.  Bands seem to play their best here, and you won't be far from the stage in this tiny place to miss any of it.  They always book great stuff.  Drinks are pretty cheap.  And the staff have minimal attitude.  Damn, the Wrens were f***ing fantastic on Thursday.

Actually such a gorgeous venue. Located right beside City Hall. It's a small and intimate venue with a bar and a second floor. The staff were really patient and kind. I went to see Olivia Dean earlier this year and atleast when I went the venue and staff had an organized process going and everyone seemed to have a great time.

Cute small venue with friendly staff and bartenders. I love that you actually get a good view of the artist, and there's a tiered balcony upstairs.Bathrooms were super clean.$10 card minimum.Affordable drinks for the area! About $9-12 for cocktails.Just docking a star because the sangria was pretty gross -- it tasted really vinegary and sour, as if the wine had spoiled.

Pretty nice venue! Went here to see The Breathing Room on Aug. 25, 2023 around 8pm (amazing!) with some friends and the audience that it attracted was great.However, the bouncer was very rude. I, unfortunately, didn't have an online ticket and they only accepted cash for walk-ins. Thankfully, there was ATM inside past the bouncer. When I tried to walk toward the ATM to get my cash, he forcefully yanked me away and told me I need cash to pay for a ticket to do so.How am I gonna get cash to pay for a ticket if you won't let me walk towards the ATM? I had to ask others to go to the ATM for me just like this other girl next to me while we waited.Understandable that they want to ensure no one sneaks in, but invading my personal space with unwarranted physical contact was rude and unnecessary; a simple verbal warning or compromise/agreement would have been much more appreciated.Visuals were great and the venue was pretty packed but it was nice to have different levels to watch the performers! Bouncer overstepping boundaries definitely hurt my experience here.
I'm not sure they are booking or doing concerts? I haven't heard anything this in the way of an update from management. Hopefully they engage soon!

Two-Story Venue. Affordable Drinks for SF. No Tax on Drinks if Paid Cash. Doors Open One Hour Before Show. COVID-19 Vaccination Checked. Free, Street Parking After 6PM Around Venue in Hayes Valley & Civic Center.

Great venue and atmosphere. Bar staff I have no complaints. All helpful. Not enough surface or trash cans options. I saw a huge soul say before show started and the building wasn't even 1/3 full. Kinda wish staff did a walk through they would've seen a huge spill on even floor. Bathrooms are decent. Overall good time and experience.

Great place love the drinks and prices. They sure bring in some great entertainment too. The crowd is awesome. I mean yknow even if you're in your own zone you still want cool people around you. I saw raye in concert here. I also saw a band I am now a fan of that I haven't even heard of before. Rock on Rickshaw!

Came here for a show last week, the energy and decorations (minimal decor but love a disco ball) were great. Bar was fully stocked and drinks were reasonable. My only critique is that it seemed like this place was well over capacity, people were packed in like sardines on both floors and on the first floor the crowd made it all the past the bar (and was crowding the bar). Curious what capacity actually is and how many people attended the show...

Went here for a comedy show, definitely enjoyed myself but was surprised with the $10 card minimum because my cider didn't hit it - got charged $3 for a soda water I didn't drink to hit the minimum. Ah well, pretty cool spot for a grungy opera house!
Super cool venue in a pretty decent area. Only about a block away from market st. Felt and looked clean. Bar had a pretty good selection. Definitely want to return!

Went here for a comedy show, definitely enjoyed myself but was surprised with the $10 card minimum because my cider didn't hit it - got charged $3 for a soda water I didn't drink to hit the minimum. Ah well, pretty cool spot for a grungy opera house!

Cute small venue with friendly staff and bartenders. I love that you actually get a good view of the artist, and there's a tiered balcony upstairs.Bathrooms were super clean.$10 card minimum.Affordable drinks for the area! About $9-12 for cocktails.Just docking a star because the sangria was pretty gross -- it tasted really vinegary and sour, as if the wine had spoiled.

Came here for a show last week, the energy and decorations (minimal decor but love a disco ball) were great. Bar was fully stocked and drinks were reasonable. My only critique is that it seemed like this place was well over capacity, people were packed in like sardines on both floors and on the first floor the crowd made it all the past the bar (and was crowding the bar). Curious what capacity actually is and how many people attended the show...

TL;DR - I love this venue The acts are always super affordable. I've seen bands like XYLO and Emo Nite here, it's always a good time. The venue isn't super big though. There's an upstairs as well - balcony that lets you have a great view!Drinks are affordable $10 min for card.

Two-Story Venue. Affordable Drinks for SF. No Tax on Drinks if Paid Cash. Doors Open One Hour Before Show. COVID-19 Vaccination Checked. Free, Street Parking After 6PM Around Venue in Hayes Valley & Civic Center.

I was simply walking by when this man took my drink and said I couldn't have it. Wtf???? I wasnt even attending the event. I was simply passing by and talking to my friends. I surely hope there's some sort of compensation to be had because that was $3.25 down the drain. I have never frequented this place and after the treatment I had, I will never come back. You have no respect for people or their personal belongings. You are disrespectful. I will never give this place any sort of patronage. I can literally see my drink on the sidewalk from this rogue bouncer.

It was a nice, intimate venue. Friendly bar staff. Spacious general admission area, cool balcony up top. My only complaint is the roof was leaky. I kept feeling drops of water from the ceiling while watching the show. Otherwise a cool place

Just went for the Miley night. The dj wasn't very good. The workers were so focused on masks when their own staff wasn't even wearing theirs. Kind of annoying when they're tapping your shoulder every minute, but you look over and the check in people and dj weren't even wearing theirs. They should also focus more on the bathrooms and work on playing good music. Because that was trash. They had the opportunity to make it fun but focused on the wrong things. Hope next time is better

Terrible experience. Poor communication from the venue to the customers. Flew out to San Fran, spent well over $1000 in travel costs to see my favorite band, showed up with my vaccine card (as required) and was denied entry due to my vaccine not being the preferred dosage/type of vaccine. Ridiculous, staff was unable to provide help besides contacting the ticket service. That can be understandable, but there was no sincerity in the miscommunication and lack of communication. I wish I would have known and been informed of the expectations before spending my saved travel money to come here. Not worth it and really wished for better service.

Decent music but terrible service. I've had better customer service from motels; the bartenders are horribly rude and snappy. I asked for a drink after just initially walking in and was immediately met with attitude from the get go. And it wasn't from a single bartender as 2 different ones i went to were extremely short with me. Not a terrible experience but the bartenders here wouldnt make me want to visit this place a second time.
We here for multiple concerts. They were both so sick and fun. These types of venues are 10x better than a big venue. I am under 18 and they let me in fine with an x on my hand. Really sick spot.

While I was waiting in line, the staff got into a fight with another customer behind me after the other customer made a comment about their ID/alcohol policy. He was not rude; just asked if he really needed to have X's sharpied on both hands to show that he was not allowed to buy alcohol. He was taken out of the line to the side.After my friends and I entered the first floor was packed, and there was no order. People were constantly pushing each other to get to the front. Then, half way through the show, a fight erupted on the floor where a man smashed his glass against a woman's head (I think because she spilled beer on him). Chaos ensued. The fight went on until the performer actually stopped and asked if something could be done. Then finally the security guard came to break up the fight....Police cars parked outside the venue as I left.Disgusting management from start to finish. I will never come back again.

A great place for a smaller/ more intimate show! Came here for a concert and was able to get right at the front of the stage. You can either stand in the lower area or stand/ sit in the upper area--the lower area goes very far back so don't arrive too late otherwise you will be far from the stage. The lower area has a bar, where they have beers on tap and they also had a cocktail special named after one of the performer's songs. They also have an upper area which is a decent size--the regulars seem to go straight up there and grab a seat on the couches and chairs. The seats are good if you don't want to be down below where you will be tight standing next to people.I like that a Rickshaw Shop is walking distance from Civic Center bart! Maybe a 10 min walk. As always be careful walking at night and try not to walk alone. If you are looking for a dinner beforehand, Cala is right next door to Rickshaw. I have never been but I've heard good things (you should make a reservation beforehand).Enjoy!

I have been living in SF overtone Year now but this place never showed up on my radar even thought it is pretty close to my crib. Never the less, yesterday "The Make Up" die a show there and it was super rad. The venue itself is just the right size, got a nice Balkony and a good cheap(for SF) full Bar, they accept all kind of cards but it will be cheaper if you pay cash. The whole interior is very chilled and feels just right burning you want something posh, this is the wrong place! I will devinetly check what bands are playing there in the future, cause I definitely come back. Ohh one word of advise, the cocktails are strong like really strong !

Been here a few times for several different shows, so it's finally time to write a review.Rickshaw is definitely one of my favorite venues considering how intimate it is. Since it's a smaller venue, you'll be close and cozy with other folks. The bartenders are chill and the drinks and strong(and reasonably priced). This place has a divey and gurngy vibe, and I wouldn't want it any other way.

A smaller venue that doesn't feel claustrophobic. We came by when doors opened for Emo Nite but we were told that they weren't quite ready and to circle back later.When we did come back, there was a small line but it moved by pretty quickly. Once in we were stamped to indicate that our tickets were checked and we had wristbands placed on us for being 21+. Once you're inside you can pretty much see to the end of the venue with the main stage at the back. To the right as you walk in are the restrooms and there is a bar on this floor as well. There are a set of stairs to the left and there was a sign indicating that there was a bar upstairs that was open and that coat check was also located up there.When we got up there the bar was definitely not functional. There was a rack where you could hang up your jackets and take a ticket but there were no staff monitoring that so someone could in theory take your jacket. The upstairs area has some couches and has a lower level where you can watch from upstairs.I didn't drink that night but they did have a spout with water to the left of the main bar so you could help yourself.All in all it was a pretty intimate venue. The event didn't seem too packed so maybe that's why there was still a decent amount of room to move around. I think some of the hiccups may have had to do with the event organizers rather than the venue.

The grungier the better! I dig small intimate venues. It can get packed like sardines on the main floor so if you're short like me, head to the second floor for the best view of the stage! Also there's a few lounge chairs upstairs if you're into sitting. Saw one of my favorite artist here and it was lit!! LOVE YOU LOLO ZOUAI!! She is a Bay Area native and a rising star so don't sleep on her!!

Had an absolute banger of a night, atmosphere, sound and lighting were all top notch. Friendly staff even went the extra mile to help me get a signature. If you looking for a venue, this is the place.

Chill quaint venue but very SF.  Went there to support a buddy's band - which was basicallly a compilation of 9 different musicians (yea the stage was a bit crowded) but the music was on point!  Drinks were VERY reasonable and the Bowie & Prince renditions were surprisingly REALLY good.  Id go back.
Four stars for the interesting rotation of events they put on, from Nerd Nite to live music. Bar is quite basic - nothing too positive or negative to say about it.
This is a great intimate venue. It's just a short walk from BART. I saw Crywolf and would come back to see another show.

This venue had pretty good acoustics and a really chill vibe. We went to see Badfish, a Sublime cover band. This place has a full bar, and I found the bartender to be pretty friendly. They had ADA seating for us, but it wasn't very comfortable. I appreciate that they gave us a good view of the stage. Overall I liked this place, but didn't like what people were doing inside of it. I hate to sound like a weenie but smoking of all kind should be outside. Some of us are really sensitive to smoke and wish ordinances would be followed. Otherwise, the casual seating was really cool and the bathroom was really nice compared to other divey places. There is room for improvement with the decor, but I understand it's supposed to have a certain look. I'd go back if it weren't for a stoner band!

What a terrible experience! The most rude and cold blooded bar tender ever. I was there Friday night, and the bar tender was serving whomever she wanted, while completely disrespecting the fact that some people got to the bar earlier (much, much earlier) and were not served. Then she takes a shot with of her friends, makesSome jokes while the rest of us were still waiting. Then went on to serve a guy who just jumped to the bar, i told her we have been waiting for a while and we got there earlier, she said with cold devilish smile "you will have to wait more". So we simply didn't buy any alcohol

Came here to see 4th Ave and the staff here kept everything organized! They were really kind throughout the day. The venue was smaller than I expected but I had no problem with that, and I love the sound system as well!! :) Definitely one of the best experiences I've had with a venue and their staff.

Love this spot. The vibes feel like a really well thought out drama club party. I have come here for both a concert and Nerd Nite and both seemed worth the price for me :) The venue is really small making the events intimate--at Nerd Nite, someone even got on stage and read a speech for her husbands anniversary present. It's nice to have a space in the middle of a city that feels like a tight knit community.

I had such a great night at the Rickshaw Stop! It was a little bit drama-filled, but I really appreciated the staff and their devotion to maintaining a safe atmosphere. I was pointed out by the bar staff (let's face it, probably with good reason) for having one too many, and then was asked to take a break outside. From there I had a small discussion with a couple members of the managerial team and they were the very best, super understanding and allowed me to go back inside and dance as long as I rein it JUST A BIT (I'm a talented and spirited dancer). Anyway, this team is fab and I appreciate all of them and I look forward to visiting again with less drama next time.

DO NOT SUPPORT THIS VENUE. The bouncers were horrible and rude. All my friend did was throw away an EMPTY beer bottle and they refused to let us in. We literally didn't even drink it there. They were incredibly rude about it and they didn't even provide us with a reasonable answer on why they couldn't let us in or provide a solution/refund. My friend and I were so sober and they treated us like garbage since they had no empathy from kicking us out. And then one of the bouncers started YELLING at us and I told him yelling was unnecessary since I'm just talking to him and then literally 3 other guys who worked there started YELLING such rude ass shit at us. There was no need to gang up on my friend and I when they were  already ruining our night. Nothing bad would have happened if they let us in, they just wanted to be bratty and ruin our night. They were all middle aged old cis white men who clearly didn't care about people or the music scene. They prob just enjoy pissing people off cuz they have a sad job of standing next to a door all day.

WORST EXPERIENCE I'VE HAD WITH A VENUE Venue bouncers/management didn't allow my friend and I entrance inside, even though we had our tickets bought in advanced, because he saw us throw away an empty beer bottle in the trash?!??? He insisted we were intoxicated when we actually sober. Had 0 proof we actually drank the empty bottle. Security and other employees also yelled at us basically attacking us. Provided no refund or other alternatives. Completely unreasonable. Nothing but ASSHOLES who are unhappy with themselves and their jobs who feel the need to talk down on young girls

Attended the Mahalia show fri 8/31.STAFF: not quite the horror show that they are reputed to be, just the typical gruff venue employee typesINSIDE: stage in back of room, bar off to side. there is a small upstairs balcony. it's a small space but didn't feel overly crowded. good set lighting. BATHROOMS????: YES. there are men+women bathrooms. women's had 2 stalls, decently clean for a hole in the wall venue. PARKING: we were able to get street parking on franklin very easily-and bc it was so late we didn't have to pay! Mahalia and Kiah both put on great sets, and it so cool to see them in such an intimate setting. I would come back to Rickshaw again. *one thing I will note is that if you're a person that has any type of issue w/ smoke or asthma or just breathing, a lot of people were smoking/vaping. and in such a small space, it was kind of heavy-so that wasn't too fun.

I saw a sold out The Hold Steady show here.  Bad experience.  I've been to 100+ venues around the country, and I've never been so crammed into a tiny club that to watch the show I had to stand in the back of the club, literally 5 feet from the bar's center, directly under bar lights shining down on me.  Talk about a terrible way to see a show.  All lit up, constantly bothered by people trying to maneuver to buy a drink, and with all the bar noise.  There was no way to move forward--the place was that inappropriately packed.  Also, the temperature inside was too warm -- running one large fan in the balcony area doesn't cut it, people -- and the small balcony has some stupid garage door-type thing pulled partially down that blocks much of the view of the stage from the balcony.  Awful, like nobody gives a sh!t who works there.On top of the issues I mention above, the staff lack common sense.  After showing my ID, they stamped a VERY large "HOT" stamp on the inside of my right wrist.  It took me 1.5 days to scrub this off of my skin, and it looked far more like a "HOT" tattoo than a club stamp.  Thanks, guys--how about using some discretion in your stamp selection.I ended up leaving the show after about six songs despite being a big fan of the band, as I just didn't feel like dealing with the nonsense.  The show two nights earlier at GAMH was night-and-day more fun to attend.  The Rickshaw Stop may be a decent place to see an unpopular, uncrowded show, but I will never return for a show that I feel might be sold out.

Went here last night for a concert. Unfortunately, my phone died so I couldn't take any pictures. This place is very white and very cis. The bouncers are rude and the space is small. There are some nice couches on the second floor and the drinks are relatively cheap but that's the only thing keeping this place from getting one star. I was not impressed by this place at all

Just a warning: don't count on the kitchen being open.Went to a concert at 8 and figure I'd just eat there, but the kitchen was closed.  The bartender told me it's sometimes open for a half hour after gates open and they serve what they might have left over.I had to run to subway during the show.  Wish the website would have said something about kitchen hours.Otherwise, this is a great, intimate venue and Ted Leo was awesome.

Idk why this revue is sooo sketch. Not sure why an independently owned company has such corporate-like policies?? My friend was not allowed in simple because her EMPTY canteen smelled like wine and she was not 21(at least not for less than a month longer.) She bought a ticket in advance and they refused to let her in. I'm thinking this place once had a lawsuit on their hands that made everyone who works there now a narc. There is one good thing, though, the manager gave our friend $12 back for the ticket price she paid (disregarding service fees) while she was crying on the sidewalk outside of the venue waiting for her uber.  She would not have even gotten that refund if it weren't for my friend and I heckling the manager. I really hate doing reviews like this because I work in customer service and deal with the absolute worst people but seriously, what gives???

Small venue. Reminds me of the places I loved in high school. If I were an 18 year old kid again I'd go to this venue every week. Now I like a few tiers on the floor or in the balcony. Tickets were cheap though so you get what you pay for. I'd much prefer the Fillmore or Orpheum. Sangria was watered down and signature drink was way too sweet. Nice sound system though.

Came for a Lauv concert last night. The venue was sold out and packed!! Although it is relatively small, it was able to comfortably hold a lot of people and has two floors. I sat on the couch on the top floor the whole night so I was away from most of the crowd but still had a good view of the stageRegular priced drinks. The downsize is that there is a $20 minimum for credit cards.. but if you're broke there's free water on tap on the side of the bar

This review is for NERD NITE Only  at Rickshaw stop:THIS IS A  quintessential SF event . A hip yet unpretentious, dive-esque bar packed with a lot of character sets the stage for 3 'talks' roughly 20 minute each  about interesting and exciting topics. Talks- they are funny, they have character, they are animated speakers giving a run down of their respective field with purpose. This night we got the history of SF's Trans culture, 20 math mysteries with graphics and dancing in 20 minutes, and how a physicist is working to understand dark matter. Each was beyond entertaining, captivating, and educational without feeling talked down to or watering down the content to much. And you walking away learning some really cool stuff.This happens the 3rd Wednesday of each month and this was the 92 hosting. Great date night, or solo event, don't bring a crew this thing fills up. Get there real early if you want to have a chair or a couch space, otherwise we did the floor up front and it was pretty nice. Cash only

Best place to dance and hear newer independent music in San Francisco. Unique and fun venue, walking distance from Hayes Valley restaurants and SFSymphony, etc.. There are a couple actual rickshaws inside, hence the name. They have a coat/back check upstairs. There is a balcony, bar with fun specials and great sound, lighting and film effects for some events I've attended.

This reminds me of a Bottom of the Hill.  An intimate venue to watch talented musicians give there ALL. Next to Cava, I could not help but hear the music pouring put into Fell Street. Stopped and talked go the bouncer and he escorted me in with great service to explore the venue.   If your type of music comes to this venue, you will love it. I remember watching Coldplay at the Warfield there first year. You may stumbnle accross the next big artist before they were famous.  5 stars all day.

You get an award for rudest bouncer of ALL TIME. Came here for Popscene/Frenship  on the hottest night ever (75 degrees at 7pm?!) and I happened to have a water bottle in my purse with like 2 ounces of rose left (from earlier in the day) in it.The bouncer asked to see my purse, I said ok, totally forgetting about the rose. So he saw my water bottle, took it out, and said "THIS IS PINK". Right, ok, so...? I said "can I drink it? I can step out of the line" And he didn't care at all that I said anything.He then threw the water bottle to this scary looking possibly homeless guy in a wife beater across the sidewalk and the wifebeater guy dumped the rose on the sidewalk, then threw the leftover bottle to a nearby trash can. Bouncer then said to me "you can purchase alcohol inside" Yeah, really? two ounces of rose would have cut back your revenue by how much? $2?Normally bouncers would give you a chance to drink it or go to back of the line or like, give you a chance to even respond. Obviously I wasn't trying to sneak it in.. the water bottle is a huge Dasani bottle! thanks for treating me like a criminal. Btw, you didn't even check the rest of my purse after you made a scene out of my water bottle. You didn't even thoroughly do your job.

This place is low key and decent for comedy shows and a place to hang out.  Due to poor acoustics and the fan at full blast, it's loud and cold.  The saving graces are the exceptionally helpful and friendly staff as well as their amazing grilled cheese sandwiches with a selection of your favorite toppings (e.g., basil, bacon, onions).  Parking can be tough on the street.  However, it's a few blocks from MUNI at Van Ness.

If I could give this place 100 stars for customer service, I would. Came here last night to see the early A R I Z O N A after paying a premium on the resale market for the early 7pm sold out show. My friend left his ticket in our Uber on the way over, so we spent the first half of the show outside trying to get that back. By the time we made it inside, we were only able to catch the last two songs. On our way out, I found myself venting to guy by the door about what had happened and how I was disappointed we missed the majority of the show. Turned out, he was the owner, and asked me and my friend to come over. He pulled out wristbands for us to attend the 10 o clock show, and told us to have a good night. We were the first to enter, and caught every song from the very front along the stage. The opening act Glades pointed the microphone at us at one point, asked us our names, and gave us a shout out. To the very generous owner who turned our night around BIG time - thank you SO much for your generous hospitality. Last night will be hard to top, but I will most definitely be coming back to Rickshaw stop again.
Nice small venue for independent and relatively new artists.
Nice intimate venue. Street parking can be hard to find but there is a parking lot around the block.

This place has a nice atmosphere for such a small venue. Sound system is decent. I've seen Powers here twice and the venue made it easy to get close to the stage. It's such an intimate venue, it was pretty easy to meet the band after the show and chat for a bit.My biggest problems are that finding nearby parking is difficult and shows start soooo late. From my experience, the headliners often don't go on until after 11. Overall, a cute quirky place to see up & coming bands!
Thuggish bouncers. Impolite security. Mean vibe. Terrible drinks. All my friends had a bad time.

I entered the club as the show was finishing. I paid the 10$ cover. They didn't say anything to me. I saw people leaving 10s after I entered.I went straight ahead to the entrance and ask if I could get my money back and leave. They refused although I entered 2 min before.

Went here for a concert for Oh Wonder and it was such a quirky, little venue. The front is a huge purple mural and you won't actually see the venue's name outside. The venue has a general admission floor and a balcony upstairs with sofas and stools. I would definitely say that the center front stools on the balcony are the best seats in the house. For someone 5'0" tall, it's always godsend to be able to see the entire set. With two bars on each floor, you won't have to struggle getting drinks either. What I love about this place the most is the intimacy you'll find here, watching your favorite band or whoever. The place can still hold a good amount of people, but the intimacy factor of it isn't reduced. If you're familiar with other venues in SF, this place is larger than Brick & Mortar, and similar to The Chapel. Also, Aaron Axelsen is here on Fridays and he seriously made the wait before the concert and in between bands poppin'. He's also on 105.3, but I'm not too sure when he's on exactly. Usually later in the evening. Anyways, I feel like he's always bringing out the dopest remixes and he's such a good source for new music. I was really stoked to find out he was the one DJing.

It was a great event! The bartenders were fast! But they truly looked like they hated me. I tipped every time...but the hate ran deep...? I didn't fart or anything, soooo...I can't say it was my fault or anything.

This is a cute little venue and I was excited to for the show I went to here. I do have one warning if you are under 21. Be very careful and don't get too close to alcohol. As soon as we got inside, one of the bouncers was staring us down and following us around. My friends who are over 21 ordered drinks, and even though I didn't get a drink, he took the first chance he got to kick us out. He was very rude and aggressive about it and so were the other workers on duty. They didn't even want to hear our side and were acting like power hungry assholes. Beware if you are under 21, you will be watched like a hawk. I don't even know if the show was good, all I can say is the bouncers are terrible.

If I could put 0 stars I would. Worst experience I've ever had at a show. The door men and managers are the most rude, obtuse, pompous, pretentious, narrow minded, petty, Inconsiderate, unsympathetic, insensitive, ignorant, and underwhelming people I've ever met. I drove 20 hours from Colorado to see Rainbow Kitten Surprise in San Francisco on spring break. I have followed the band since their first album in 2013 and couldn't have been more stoked to see my favorite band on their first tour. I purchased my ticket months in advance for the show. When we showed up at the door my ticket wouldn't scan. The manager came over and told me I bought the ticket for the earlier 5 o clock show they had and that I'd have to buy another ticket to get in. Ticket says 5pm-2 am. Never have I heard of a venue playing 2 shows in the same night. After pleading my case and telling him how far I came to see the show he told there was nothing he could do. (Meaning he's just a lazy manager) And subsequently kicked me out because he just decided he didn't want to argue with me.

The female bartender tonight was AWFUL, rude, but mostly slow.  If you want to make $$$ for yourself and your fellow bartenders, learn how to multi-task or fuck off.  It's not that hard.  If you hate what you do I garentee everyone around knows.
Do not bother to come to this place. First the security is the most rude Guy in the world. Very small place, super hot. the drinks are awful.

First time at Rickshaw Stop; didn't really know what to expect. I went there to see LÉON. I took BART in so I didn't have to deal with parking. Was about 8 mins from Civic/Downtown to Fell and Van Ness so super easy to get there. From the person checking ID's, to the stage crew - every single person was very nice, friendly and up beat. The balcony is cool, the couch in the back is comfy, the wooden boxes to sit or stand on on the sides of the room are a great touch. The sound system is awesome! Not too loud and high quality sound! I had a great time to see an awesome singer. The beer was reasonably priced and the bartenders are way hot! Would not hesitate to see another show there - I had a great time!
great venue, great music always, great crowd always , always professional and respectful security, bartenders really helpful

Great venue! A smaller club, but actually lots of space! I like to go upstairs to the balcony, there are usually some chairs there and you can lean against the railing and see the show perfectly. There is also a bar up there as well as the coat check. Lots of parking lots with reasonable rates nearby.

I can't say that I'm still a fan of the Rickshaw Stop. I like the small intimate size. And I like that the restrooms are by the door and there's hardly ever a wait. Drinks are pretty cheap and I like that the water is self-service at the end of the bar. But the shows start late and go really long. The doors don't open until 8 o'clock, and the first act doesn't usually go on until 8:45. And don't expect the main act until well after 10. At the last show, there was a half hour wait between the two. The place was full, the stage was set, and everyone was antsy and ready to go. Is it a ploy to sell more drinks? It might not bother me if it a was the weekend but on a weeknight when I still need to take public transportation home and get up at 6:30 the next morning to go back to work, I'd like to wrap up at a reasonable hour. Subsequently. every time I've been here, I've had to leave before the main act was over which sucks. Another thing is that sound system isn't very good. I didn't realize how bad until I saw a couple of shows at The Independent for a few dollars more on the ticket price. I could hear every word the singers were singing. At the Rickshaw, the bass is really low and throbbing sometimes to the point of ridiculousness. Even in the intimate moments of songs, when the artist is playing the keyboard and singing, the sound is muddy and distorted. Not OK! They do have a balcony with a few seats but they'll be taken early by people who know they're in it for a long haul.

I saw Mako here. I can't complain much -- it was a small, intimate venue with hipster vibes, which I really liked. You get a great view of whoever's performing no matter where you are on the floor. The crowd, thankfully, isn't too unruly. The tickets were also very, very cheap - $36 for two tickets after taxes/fees and everything!I only have a few minor complaints. The sound system could have been better -- when a violinist was playing, I could barely hear that part, which was sad, because the violinist is a big part of the song. Though I'm not sure how much of that is the performer's fault vs. the venue's fault.The ticket also said 8pm, but Mako didn't start playing until much later -- probably around 10. I was a little annoyed at the time, as I didn't know how much time I was allotted to skip the opening act to finish up a task I needed to do. I'd have liked a little more transparency in terms of when the acts started/finished.But those are only minor issues. I totally recommend this place for concerts, and I wouldn't mind going back at all.
Saw Hayley Kiyoko here. LOVED the sound quality. Pretty friendly staff at the bar and door and great meet and greet experience.

Place is super small. Sound system could be better. When they turn on the AC starts leaking from the ceiling so we was super uncomfortable having water drop on top of your head. If you plan on getting super drunk here just don't throw up because once someone throws up.... its hard to escape the smell cause the place is so small.

Saw Lewis Del Mar here and they were amazing. I think the tickets were $15 after fees which is unheard of.This venue is a gem for shows, it's small so it's very intimate. There's an upstairs that has seats but I didn't venture up there. There's a bar on the first floor and they take cards, and there's a $20 minimum. We got there around 8:30 and we were right up against the stage. Chill venue with very friendly staff, I can't wait to see someone else there.

This place seemed quite disorganized and poorly run. For a concert supposed to start at 8, the line didn't even start entering til 8:20. Once inside we waited, listening to bad DJ music, for a pointless half-hour until the opening act showed up, so it was nearly 9 before anything worthwhile began.The opener spent far too much of his set rambling aimlessly instead of singing, and repeatedly/effusively thanking us for showing up. After his set we waited through another 45-minute nothingness for the headliner, who performed for barely an hour.This kind of entertainment ratio is insane. Worse yet, the place has almost no seating to speak of, save for a dozen or so wooden cubes around the edges. We won't be back.

Had an amazing time here for a Calum Scott concert, his first time in SF! Love that the rickshaw is such a small intimate space and can bring in artists like Calum Scott who are so talented and genuinely excited to be performing.Only downside for me is...It's basically standing room only....and I'm not as young as I used to be.

The venue itself is cool I like it there I went for emo nite n had alot of fun. My issues were with staff. Couple of the bartenders are rude and most of the people working seem to hate their jobs. More specifically, someone broke a glass by the stage n my friends and I tried to move it out of the way so nobody would get hurt. As an employee was walking by collecting glasses, I stopped him to let him know one broke. He didn't stop or even look at me just replied with a snobby attitude "I don't have anything to clean it with" and just walked away. YES I CAN SEE THAT BECAUSE I'M NOT BLIND I was letting you know so someone wouldn't get hurt because you kinda work there don't have to be a douchebag. Anyway, some of the staff is my only complaint otherwise it's a cool venue.

Nerd nite - venue will be packed and seats will be quickly taken.  Seats are hard.  Our experience was saved by the 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea presentation which was fantastic otherwise it'd be 2 stars.

I love this venue! I came to see Reeve Carney, who was absolutely amazing, here last night. Been here for a couple other shows in the past. The venue is very intimate, the ambiance is nice, and the layout is very open for it being such a small place. The guy working the door was super funny and the bartenders were friendly. Can't wait to come back again for the next show!

This place always seems to have the best upcoming indie acts. Bigger venues like The Fillmore and Bill Graham might have some of the bigger names, but whenever I discover a really great new indie band and see they're playing in SF, it seems like almost every time they're playing at rickshaw. I go to a concert at least once a week, and over half of them have been at Rickshaw, and it's not like I try to go there I just kind of end up there after looking for shows I'll like. It's a small, intimate venue, and much more relaxed than places like the fillmore. I've seen people standing on benches and even sitting on the piano (down on the floor, not the stage) and no one seemed to mind. This could be handy if you're short, especially since it's a fairly low stage so if you're shorter it can be a little harder to see (it's not too bad for the short folks out there though, in addition to standing on the furniture you can pretty much show up 10 minutes before the music starts and secure a spot in the front, or go off to the side if you don't mind the awkward angle but still want to see).The sound system sounds great, though I'm not audiophile so I cant really say much about the quality other than it seems perfectly fine. I can say though that they've probably got the best lighting system of any similarly sized venue in town, and they've just put in four brand new high tech led spotlights that look fantastic, and this is in addition to what was already a really nice looking set. Once the music starts it looks absolutely gorgeous on stage, and unfortunately your phone camera will never do it justice.The shows always are listed at 8, but they always start the music 40-50 min after, it seems to be a rule that the artists wait until at least 8:40 to start. The headliner will usually start at around ten.I don't drink, so unfortunately can't tell you much about the drink quality or pricing. They do always have a drink themed on the band that'll be playing, so it's kinda fun to see what kind of drink related puns they come up with.My biggest complaint is the lack of box office hours, you can only buy the tickets online or at the door of the specific show (can't buy tickets for a different show). I've heard you can buy the tickets for there at the independent and some other places, but I've never tried it. Also it's cash only, which is kind of annoying. But hey, buying the ticket is always the worst part of a concert right?This is a great venue, very conveniently placed (right smack in the middle of town and two blocks away from bart/muni underground), cheap tickets (usually around $14 at the door), great sound and lighting, and most important of all always having the best acts, I plan on returning often

This place is the best. They book amazing bands. They have one great bartender and the red velvet curtains make me want cake and the stage is the perfect height to scope all the cute bois  and the I stood and a/c all over my face, great air circulation and even though one of their strands of Christmas lights was out I can forgive them bc the fog machine was sooooOoOoO dank. All in all five stars

Came here to see The Drums and it was a perfect size for an obscure show like this. That is the aspect I liked the most about this venue, how you can get very close to the stage and everything is cozily compact without making it feel uncomfortably crowded or hot. The acoustics are great too!There is a bar to the right of the stage and a small seating area to the left. Also, there is some outdoor seating which is convenient when waiting for doors to open. Whether you know the musicians or not, the people, location and size of this place makes it so easy to enjoy an intimate show for an affordable price. Plus, the performers are clearly displayed on their front sign which I always enjoy scoping out when along Van Ness. :)

Love the venue. BUT last night my friend got jumped by a group of about 8 guys. They claimed he knocked over one of their drinks. Security (pink hair) held him in place while they repeatedly punched him and made him defenseless. He did not help stop the fight he made the outcome much worse. Another security guard was friends with the violent group. After apologizing to us for what had happened they asked us to leave. We wasted money on the tickets and drinks. Also got charged $40 at the bar and only ordered one drink.

Really cool place with horribly rude staff. I bought tickets in advance to Jerry Folk with my significant other. I went into the venue and I am a few weeks out from my 21st birthday while my significant other is 24 years old. Neither of us bought drinks the entire night, being that we were only there about an hour. Someone came up to me that worked there and accused me of scrubbing the x'es off of my hand that indicated I was under 21. In all honesty I DID NOT do that. I used the bathroom about four times while I was there and washed my hands each time so the x'es of course washed off slightly but you could still see them on my hand. He asked me to go back to the bouncer in the front to re-mark my hands in which I was completely cooperative with, even after feeling very offended and  accused. The bouncer asked me what had happened and again I repeated to him that I had used that bathroom several times that night to which he accused me of drinking before hand and would not let me back into the rickshaw, AFTER I had paid beforehand for the specific DJ playing that night. With no protest, my s/o and I left and I feel extremely upset at the way this situation was handled tonight and will be letting ALL of my friends from college know that this place sucks going out to. I will let them know that that staff there is unfair and rude to those who may be underage and in general. I will let my friends of age know to never give there business to a theatre that accuses innocent customers of doing something wrong.

Worst customer service ever. The bouncer said he was "too stressed out" to answer our questions about ticket sales. Shouldn't you be prepared for much more stressful situations if you've chosen a career as a bouncer? They were extremely rude and dismissive and seemed totally unprepared to handle a big event. Would not go here on a Friday or Saturday night. Or ever, for that matter. Will never come here again!

As an SF native, The Rickshaw Stop is my favorite venues in the city. Come here to see unknown bands before they get big. Ticket prices are reasonable, they have games like foosball and skeeball, and it's walking distance from Hayes Valley, which hosts many wonderful bars and restaurants (some of my favorite being Two Sisters, Smuggler's Cove, and Domo Sushi). I would 100% suggest buying a ticket to a band you've never heard of and attending with an open mind :)
Great little venue with awesome sound, look and ambiance.

Pretty sweet venue! Not huge and not grossly crowded either. There's an upstairs and downstairs and you can see the performer pretty well in either area. $20 min for card I believe for the bar. It was like a $20 cover fee too when I went.
The Lukas graham show was fantastic!!! The girl at door taking the tickets was unnecessarily rude though :/

I've been here twice! Once for Mikky Ekko, and the other time for Oh Wonder. The place itself is fairly small. The bar is located on the right side and there's also an upstairs area for stage viewing. There's also a bar upstairs also. For the performances, the crowd literally starts at the edge of the stage. Gives off an intimate vibe with the artists that I really enjoy. Comfy and cool place overall.

Came here on a Friday night to see Crywolf. The price of the drinks was reasonable for the amount of alcohol. We got 4 whiskey shots with chase and 2 irish car bombs for 60 dollars. The place was great for Crywolf concert! We got to be very close to him. The bathroom there was also decently clean. Definitely recommend this place for small venues.

I was here again for Nerd Nite where they have 3 speakers talk on a subject they have expertise on. Tonight's topics were stem cell research, architectural history, and the prison system. I had a nice time, but this venue was too tight for all the people. People were sitting on the floor or sitting in chairs. There was beer sloshed everywhere. It was just too hectic. Nerd Nite should be in an office space, church, library...anywhere with enough space for people to sit.

I attended a concert here. The tickets had sold out weeks before, it is a small venue so need to act fast.  Enjoyed the drinks and the cozy environment. It is not a big venue although still lots of space to dance and it does not feel like cramped quarters. We had a major issue with the air conditioning that made it pretty bad after the first three songs. They fixed it mid concert but the downstairs back area never got any better, closer to the stage was ok.

For Nerd NiteKey tips- Buy tickets ahead of time (as in a week ahead of time). They do sell out. They sell 30 tickets at the door but even when buckets of rain were falling from the sky there was a line of people who had been waiting 30+ minutes for these standby tickets.- Line up ~6:30p if you want seats and a clear view- Come with an open mindThe venue was easy to find by Van Ness and Fell. Plus there will likely be a long line forming anyway. The location itself lacked seating leaving many on the floor and uncertainty whether there was a clear escape route (say if I needed to visit the ladies room). Thankfully people at the floor sat down and my view from a chair was perfect. They serve food and drink if you are hungry but I personally didn't feel like throwing $8 for a grilled cheese. As for nerd nite itself, I appreciate that there were 3 different topics; however it really is a hit or miss. It is best to buy a ticket if you have interest in at least one of the topics because otherwise these are volunteer lecturers and not professional speakers.

There's no doubt about it, the Rickshaw has been my favorite venue since I was in high school. Not too far from Civic Center of you don't mind trudging through the  Burger King favela, you'll find yourself at this oasis on Fell, a place with cheap drinks ($10 card minimum guys, sorry!) and the best artists, be they well-known or relatively unknown. The place has one charming quality that I can't seem to find anywhere else-- intimacy. To come as close as you can to your favorite artists, completely in their element, there's something raw and authentic. Someone will miss a note or botch a cord and nobody feels shy about it, artists feel a certain openness here that is unfound anywhere else I've been. When I see a show here, it's always a chill crowd and an honest, interactive experience. And at be end of the night, I stumble through the homeless encampment with my stolen band poster (sorry again Rickshaw!) and grab some chicken fries before I hop on BART.   The to-go spot.

Rickshaw Stop is such an intimate venue. It's VERY small. I've been here twice now for two different shows -- one was for a sold out show (Oh Wonder). The merch table is usually set up by the front door, near the restrooms. There's a bar downstairs. $20 minimum on cards. A beer & a jack & coke was ~$14. The stage is set up downstairs and it's literally the smallest stage I've ever seen. There definitely isn't very much room on the stage, but the dancefloor is decent sized. It makes the shows very intimate since you can get right up close and personal with your favorite artists. There is also an upstairs balcony area, which is nice when you go to the really packed shows. If you're short like me, it's fantastic being up there because then you can still see LOL. Sound quality is pretty great, since the venue is so small ya know, it's not too hard to see/hear everything very well. What else is there to say? Great bar/venue to see some of your favorite artists in a super intimate setting. I would definitely recommend checking out a show here if you get the chance!

It's a nice small venue. Went there for the first time to see Oh Wonder. Despite the small size, the venue can still pack quite a number of people, so if you're attending a sold out show, go early if you want to be close to the front. There's a balcony as well. I didn't get a chance to check it out, but there are seats up there (ground floor is standing room only). The people working there were nice, and I'd probably go back if there's ever an artist I like performing there.

Cool little spot to see a show.  Good prices on booze and easy to get drinks.  Only downside is the artists go on very late. We showed up around 10 or 10:30pm here to see Reptar and the opening act had just started playing.  Good thing we were not planning on taking the Caltrain back to Palo Alto - Reptar didn't go on until after 11:30pm.

RE: Party venueThis venue was recommended to me through a colleague and as soon as we visited the space, we were sold. Thanks to Dan, Harp, and their team, we had the best corporate holiday party our staff has ever had! Dan was incredible to work with and made sure we got a great deal. He was easy-going, helpful, and genuinely excited about the event which made planning so much more enjoyable. They made setup and cleanup a breeze, allowed us to move things around to fit our party's needs, and even helped decorate with the holiday vibe we were going for. You could tell everyone wanted to help us have a good time and keep things running smoothly. The drinks were good (they let us have 2 custom drinks on the menu which was fun and popular among guests), the bar service was fast and easy (we used the drink ticket approach), and Dan was fast and easy to communicate with throughout the entire process. Parking and safety were non-issues, there was plenty of space for our 150+ guests, and again the vibe the space lends itself to is just right for a trendy mingling and festive atmosphere.If you're looking for a hip, cool place to throw a party, this is it! Seriously, give them a call.

I loved the vibe, I loved the band, I loved the venue.....except for THE SOUND. It was so loud that you could not distinguish one guitar from the other...the bass was this huge thumping drone, and forget about understanding any lyrics. At one point (on 12/14/15) Murray Lightburn from the Dears was onstage with just an acoustic guitar doing a beautiful song with quiet dynamics, and it was still so loud that everyone kept their earplugs in. It's just ridiculous. In an intimate atmosphere you should be able to hear EVERYTHING. I actually went up to the guy at the booth in between bands and politely said it was too loud. He just shrugged. The same deal at the Bottom of the Hill...volume to the point of mandatory earplugs and total quality distortion. Disappointing....because the venue is great otherwise.

If a new band books a gig at Rickshaw, you can bet they're going to start making it big in due time (Ellie Goulding, Lily Allen, Bastille, Sam Smith, The Wombats, etc.) Overall, i love this venue and the hidden crazy gem that it is. Rickshaw is small enough so that if you get there early, you can literally be inches away from the performers, but it's also large enough so that you can get down and groovy upstairs and in the back. However, it does get insanely packed, so be warned if you're going to a sold out show. If a show is sold out and you are kicking yourself in the butt for not getting tickets in time, have no fear! They usually sell a limited number of tickets at the door, so get there early if you want to score tickets. There is also an open dance floor after the gig is over, which is always fun. The performances are always fantastic and if you're from the bay, I highly recommend seeing a show during your time here. It's definitely a bucket list venue for the avid concertgoer.

You're an idiot if you rated Rickshaw 3 stars or less.  This small, cozy venue is pulling in some serious talent.  The tickets are cheap, the drinks are strong and cheap, and staff is attentive.  What's not to like? Idiots.

I've been here multiple times and every time I go the bouncers are assholes. I was physically and verbally assaulted by a woman bartender for accidentally bumping into her on the dance floor. They are very strict on underage drinking, and every time I go I see young women/men getting kicked out way too aggressively and unnecessarily yelled at.I understand wanting to enforce an important rule, but it seems like all it's doing is giving the people that work there leeway to push around and LITERALLY throw out paying customers.  Overall though, the venue is mediocre, the crowd is alright and the drinks are okay.

Great venue for intimate shows with up-and-coming artists, nice staff, and pleasant atmosphere. I saw Mikky Ekko here in October, and the whole experience was delightful (despite the intoxicated girl in front of me staggering back into me every two minutes). After the show, Mikky Ekko and Transviolet (opening band) stuck around to meet fans, and that was awesome too. I would most certainly come back for more shows.

Rude people spilling drinks on me despite my polite protests. Bar tenders are great!  Crowd was rude and undesirable considering the offender was literally pouring his drink on his friend next to me multiple times during the night.

Rickshaw Stop is a great venue to see the latest upcoming artists before they make it big.  It's also the best place to see upcoming artists before they never make it big.  It's also a great place to get a pint of red bull and vodka for $8 (WHAAAT?)I'm a bit of a concert fiend, if you will.  I find myself at all the hottest venues seeing all the major acts before they become big (humblebrag?).  Rickshaw is one of the great places to do this.  In truth, you don't know what you're going to get at this place, but it'll probably good.  In truth, I had a friend whose purse got stolen here and that was kind of a bummer.This city needs more venues like Rickshaw Stop.  However, beware dear reader that some shows are 18+ and some are 21+ and you might not be sure which one you're about to go see (gasp)!  If you're a 21+ kind of person then double check before you agree to get down with that musak.One of the major pluses of Rickshaw is that you can get so close to the stage you can practically smell the sweat of the performers, if you're into that.  It's intimate, small, with good acoustics and great acts.  There's a bit of a swindler crowd that likes to prey on the vulnerable, but if you come lightly dressed you should be okay!

Great atmosphere, solid drink prices, and rad DJ's/themed nights. Club 1994, thoughhhh! Also, free hair styling for Bardot-A-Go-Go. Nuff' said.The bar staff is super chill, and the redheaded security dudes are some of the nicest people I've met. Not even kidding. If I have questions about late night places to grab a drunken bite, they always give me good options. Some of the events seem to sell out hella quick, so my advice is getting tickets in advance/arriving earlier. Love this place!
Been here twice for some indie shows. Sound is good. Walls are soft and comfy...

Took out $60 from their ATM before watching a friends show, and woke up the next morning with $45. Drinks are cheap, music is good, it's not so oppressively crowded that you can't go to the bar or the bathroom and make it back to your spot in the audience. Couch space available for anyone that needs to take a seat, too. Best part: CLOSE TO BART. Yay.
My homie lost all of his stuff but an employee who looked as if he belonged to the band that is Tame Impala helped him return his belongings Thanks rickshaw stop

My first yelp review because that's how bad this experience was. I've been an avid Nerd Nite attendee for over two years now and absolutely love the presentations. I've always known it can get a bit full and you need to get there early to secure a seat or a spot on the floor. We arrived right at 7 when the doors opened, grabbed a seat at a bench upstairs near the rail. At 8 when the show started we were told we couldn't sit at the bench and needed to find a new place to sit. After an hour of securing that spot. There was no place to even stand and half the people standing near the bar couldn't see the presentations. They pack the bar in past maximum capacity, the staff is unbelievably rude and it is no longer worth going to nerd nite because of how crappy the venue is.

My friend and I were drinking sunny d in line for a free show. The guy carding everyone took our sunny d bottles and said we weren't getting in. He didn't explain anything. He just took our bottles, tore off my wrist band, crossed out my friend's X's on her hands and told us we weren't getting in.

I went here with my boyfriend to watch O and Astronauts, etc.!!  This venue is pretty small but has a mezzanine where you can sit and not be so stuck in the crowd.  We were standing at the front of the stage...and it was FREEZING!!! But we stayed at the front because we totally thought we were gonna see toro y moi (according to bandsintown he was gonna dj) ((but it never happened))... anyway, the room did not get any warmer for me and my bf even when the final act came on and the crowd actually started to move around and dance more.  if u want to be at the front where the stage is, then wear 10 jackets or dance constantly so u dont freeze to death.  otherwise, i suggest staying in the middle of the crowd, on the balcony, or anywhere else where the ac wont be blowing straight at you.
My experience was very good,They had good music,Drinks were ok and well priced they had two floors last night there was plenty of space on both but still not a dead club

Went here for my first time to see Brandon Flowers 2 weeks ago. Its small but intimate. I was so close to him! *dreamy sigh*. Anyway, It's a small venue with an upstairs area that I didn't go check out cuz I was too close to the stage to want to go venture off lol .. Affordable stiff drinks and good music. Will most likely go back for a night out.

Such a great venue!  Great staff, cool area and the drinks were stiff! Had the most amazing time enjoying the concert and dancing to the DJ all night! No matter where you stand you will have a perfect view of the show!!

My first time I'm San Francisco,  I was looking on Yelp for a cool place to watch some bands play.  It was $12 to get in.  The venue was a good size. Very beautifully decorated.  The people here were chill.  Some people were too comfortable to be near me but it's alright,  the more close the merrier. The bands were awesome some kind that was enjoyable.  I would come back here again.  Looking forward to it again sometime in the near future when I come  back again.  Until the next time

...came out of Uber and steeped in the line to attend "kafana balkan" and the security guard out of nowhere started to be rude on me ant the girl with me, we didn't even say a word when he started yelling for attention!
Fun great venue just not a fan of how they drag out the headliner's perform time.
Popscene is really fun!  I saw a great band here but the lineup was really late. Seemed like the drinks were good. Balcony was great for some seating.

If you want funky,  come here,  if you want electro swing, come here,  if you want artists you've never heard of and don't want to tell anyone about because there so good,  come here.  The vibe is always good,  the amount of people can be much at times,  but the music never disappoints
Rickshaw hosts some really fun events, but use cash; DO NOT use your card at the bar because the bartenders will take liberties with your tab.

To put it simply, Rickshaw Stop is like an insane asylum, with a stage. It's just a huge box of a room, with cushion-like walls. If not for the stage, the lights, and the bar in the back, I'd think I'd have gone crazy. Instead, you've got some great tunes to go crazy about.Been here just a few times now. Saw the Fratellis and Monarchy here. Sound for each band was pretty great. I think they could have kicked it up a notch when it comes to the loudness, but then again we don't all wanna be deaf right? The venue itself is small enough for you to get a pretty decent view of the band from wherever you are. They've also got a pretty nifty little upstairs balcony if you want to have a seat as well. Perfect for those post-25 concert vets whose knees can't take standing for hours on end.They've got themselves a bar, but that's about it when it comes to that. They usually have a few nightly specials, but other than that it's just a kinda small bar. The Rickshaw is a pretty fun spot for concerts. Yet another reliable venue in the city!

This club venue has potential. The inside is fairly small and when it gets crowded, it can get pretty humid with all of human body heat. Its lack of ventilation makes it hard to dance on the dance floor for a long period of time without breaking out sweats. The one particular event that I go here is Gameboi, they have a great crowd and  a lot of pop music. They even play occasional K-pop. It is a 18+ up place, those over 21 will get a wristband to show they are able to drink while those under that age group will be "X" (permanent marker X on both hands LOL).
Sosh made me think the ping pong night would be fun. I was miserably disappointed.  Dirty hipsters, 1 ping pong table, "around the world ping pong", sad decorum. +1 star for lack of food poisoning.

I was finally able to see a show at Rickshaw Stop just a few weeks ago. I nabbed tickets for Cathedrals' EP release party for Popscene. We arrived around 10:15ish and there was already a long line out the door. It was packed for a Thursday night. When we walked in, we decided to take a look upstairs, where there was a small bar and a balcony with a view of the dance floor and stage. The ceiling was pretty low on the second level. Back downstairs, we bought a couple drinks (there's a minimum if you wanna use a credit card) and made our way toward the stage. The sound was pretty good. Props to the lighting guys too. There wasn't much decor except for the velvet curtain that wrapped around the venue and the visuals that were projected onto the screen behind the stage. Ladies room had 2 stalls..it wasn't super clean, but we survived. There was one spot on the floor where a fan was blasting..good if you need some air, bad if you're trying to keep your DO in one place.The cool thing was that the performers could only access the backstage area by walking through the left side of the dance floor, so we were able to say hello and grab a photo with Brodie as she walked by. Total fan girl moment.I was stoked to finally get tickets to a show at Rickshaw Stop since it is a pretty intimate venue. Expect anyone that performs here to blow up within a couple months..i.e. Jessie Ware, Sam Smith, and pretty soon Cathedrals!

Background: I went here for the Berlin Pingpong event hosted by....Sosh? I don't know who hosted it but I saw it on Sosh.Positives: diverse demographic, CHHHHEEEAAPPP drinks, takes credit card, they host events like Berlin ping pong...Negatives: the demographic is dirty hipsters,  they play (or at least when I went) did not play the best hip hop music, it was very underground and very awful, the atmosphere is just poorly decorated and poorly up kept

Funky lil spot on Fell for a casual dance-party in what feels like your weird neighbor's garage. Have now been to Rickshaw Stop twice and each time feels like a hipster house party. (ie-you leave feeling a little bit cooler than you came.) The venue is very small, or shall I say "intimate," so definitely a place you could come to alone. There is also a lounge type area upstairs with VERYYY comfortable couches if you're tryna take a quick snooze.They tend to cater to quirky but SOLID indie bands and tickets are cheappp so even if you're not super familiar with the band, chances are you'll have fun, or at least enjoy a nice sit on their couches.

I go here for Gameboi and love it. The single stage and dance floor keep things centralized and for those who need to get out of the crowd, the upstairs is a lounge area. Drinks are cheap and the bartenders are quick.

This and the Bottom of the Hill have become my two favorite spots to catch a concert in the city.The venue is located in Hayes Valley, which makes it super easy to get to from the Van Ness muni-metro and most buses. The location is also ideal for grabbing a bite before the show (try Rich Table or Chez Maman) and some cocktails after (try Absinthe or Brass Tacks).The space itself is large enough to get some great traveling bands, but small enough to feel very intimate. The stage isn't raised very high and there isn't any noticeable security or barriers set up so it's a great experience to watch the bands perform up close (just watch your head for any flying limbs from the circle pit at punk/metal shows). Btw, there's a mezzanine level with two levels of couches and benches if you want to stay out of the mix.Lastly, the shows are typically super cheap for SF standards ($10-20) as are the drinks. The bartenders are pretty fast and friendly as well, so that's a huge win.
Cool little venue. Cheap tickets. Strong drinks. Clean bathroom. Good mix of people. Nice bartenders.
Came here to see Sam Smith, great intimate venue, cash only drinks, great concert experience

The Rickshaw Shop is a nice little event venue located near the Civic Center.  I came here for the Kina Grannis concert and thoroughly enjoyed my time.  It has an intimate setting with both a top and bottom floor for the audience to watch.  There's a nice bar in the back with well drinks and beers for your to enjoy while you're at your concert.  Most importantly, the venue was well ventilated, air-conditioned, and never felt uncomfortable for the viewers.  If you have a concert here, you'll always have a great view and a wonderful experience!

This review is for the staff. They had a horrible bouncer outside The Moth event yesterday. He harassed my friend because she had a paper driver's license while she was waiting on the plastic one to be sent. She is 29 years old, come on. When he checked my ID he didn't even see my birth date because it was in my wallet and he didn't even ask me to take it out. He was condescending, rude and just plain nasty!! After harassing my friend about a LEGAL paper ID that could be scanned to prove was real (he refused to try) he admitted the event was all ages and that he couldn't keep her from coming in. So he wasted 10 minutes of our time harassing her when he could have just let her in because it was all ages. We missed the opening of the Moth and we were just there to support the event! He marked her hands with 2 huge Xs in sharpie (very dramatic) and said you better not wash these off, you better not wash these off etc. We told him we weren't interesting in drinking we just wanted to see the show but he was relentless to show us he was on a power trip and in control. Horrible experience. I would not come back if he was the bouncer, I would literally turn around and walk away because who wants to deal with a hostile bouncer who is on a power trip.

A really tiny venue so you're really up close and personal. We saw a really cool show with A Tribe Called Red. Even at the back, you could see them easily.
