They had looping movie scenes being projected on a giant screen on the stage. If you went to the bar in the back, there was absolutely no crowd. Our tickets said doors open at 8pm; A Tribe Called Red didn't start until 10:45pm, which we unfortunately didn't know until we got to the door at about 9pm - we actually just got our hands stamped, biked back home to the Mission, and came back out around 10:30pm. It was lucky that they allow reentry! I should've called ahead to find out when they were starting.

Went to this place for a 90's party...it was awesome, drinks were decently priced, the music was good and they kept the party going till 2am. Not super huge, but big enough to have a good vibe and get your dance on

Doesn't answer phone calls or email. You're catering to a local crowd, so good for you - the problem is that I'm "local," just not local enough to drive over there. Have fun on your island. PS, why bother having contact info on your website?

I expected a loud, hot, small, crowded venue when I found out the concert I was going to was here. I was pleasantly surprised when I got in. While it was an acoustic scaled-down set (with arranged chairs downstairs--I was told that is not normal and usually it's just an open space), there was ample non-assigned seating upstairs and a large bar downstairs where you could chill at the entire time. As long as I have something to lean on, standing ain't so bad. Bud was $3, which was incredible. I expected beers to be a minimum $6 since it's a concert venue, but that was not the case. A little annoyed a bearded bartender man bussed a half full beer I had on the bar (I ran to the bathroom, guess I should have went napkin over the top), but another bartender, upon hearing my plight, comped me a Dos Equis for the trouble, which was awesome. I'm sure they don't all run this smoothly, but definitely left satisfied.

Can't tell what exactly the vibe is here, but this place certainly tops my list on SF venues because it gets all of it right:1) Cheap drinks (nice and stiff too)2) Unique vibe (you have corrugated metal and lights and vintage bikes and outdoor chairs everywhere... Maybe the theme is downtown Thailand?)3) Usually a good crowd4) Effective layout5) Nice sound system The acts that pass through tend to be on the underground side, but that tends to be the draw of this place. Go on a random night with some friends and you might find yourself with the next Lorde or LCD Soundsystem.

What a way to spend a Thursday night!  Doors opened around 9:30 to a fairly empty club...however that changed pretty quickly.  A great DJ opened up the night, definitely got the crowd moving.  Then a two band set - Echosmith and Birds of Tokyo...never heard of them before but they are now on my radar.  Drinks were cheap and generous, bartenders cool and the crowd completely random.  Will definitely go back.

Cheap drinks, cheap tickets, intimate venue and rock n roll. What more could you ask for? There is a great mix of people (rockabilly, motorcycle riding dudes, old dudes, yuppies (is that still a thing?), hippies, etc.) which makes for good people watching. Ended up standing during most of the show, which was nice. Much love to Rickshaw Stop for cranking up the A/C above the stage - vents facing the audience - once people started moving and the interior temperature started rising.Super friendly bartenders. The bathroom was as clean as you are going to find in a bar/music venue.

The Rickshaw Shop, is a fantastic rock n roll club.  I traveled here to see Leslie and the Ly's from Iowa, While I was in town!  Funny I was seeing and Iowa band cause the Rickshaw reminds me a lot of the Vaudeville Mews in Des Moines, IA.. With the excellent stage site from the balcony!  The sound in the room was fabulous and the bartenders were wonderful!One of the bartenders saw my Minnesota Vikings credit card, and pulled her's out and said, "You are drinking for Free all night!"  This was not the case but lucky for me they did have some cheaper brews then most places I hung in San Fran.This place some might consider a diver bar, but I thought it was defiantly pretty clean and the bathrooms were well taken care of! All in all a stellar music venue and a must stop if your going to check out a show in San Fran!

I've been to practically every single music venue in the SF bay area and somehow just managed to check out the rickshaw stop for the first time last Thursday to see an SF Popscene show.  Like other reviewers of this place I was a little discouraged to find out the super late starting time of the show (doors at 9:30!) but as soon as I walked in I felt acquainted with the pseudo-hipster yet unique vibe of this small 200-person or so venue.I'm a big fan of the 2 level upstairs balcony if you can manage to snag a seat before the show.  The sound quality is decent, the drinks are moderately priced and there isn't really a bad spot in the house.  Most acts that play here are relatively underground but that's part of its charm.

I've seen a few of my favorite Indie groups here and have always had an enjoyable time.  There's seating upstairs if you don't want to stand all night with 2 bar areas.  There is no type of food served there so be sure to grab a bite before.  There is a girl selling candy for those with a sweet tooth though. haha
love the vibe and music played here. sick af. saw many good shows there. can get personal with artist. good drinks good company good time. always down to try things once.
Just moved to SF from LA. Missed the LA indie music scene until I found the Rickshaw Stop. Great times - highly recommended.

reasons why i love this venue:very small and intimateexcellent sound qualityno hard tickets sold - discourages scalpersnever a bad seat in the house given the sizecheap tickets - $15what i don't likeTHE SHOWS START SUPER LATE!!i'm talking like 11:30 on a tuesday.  i'm a working grandma, i just can't handle those kinds of hours.  so yeah, don't show up at 9pm for an 8pm show.  chances are you'll be wasted by the time the band shows up at 11.also if you are front row, watch out for flying drumsticks.  i took one to the eye a few weeks ago, right after getting LASIK no less.  talk about freakout!
Random Wednesday I would drop by... and never be disappointed. Any bands targeting this bar won't be disappointed either.

Love this spot.  Been coming here for years.  It has a very intimate, and dive feel.  People in here are cool cats.  Good chance you will catch a great indie band here.  I have seen a lot of good bands here, that end up getting super popular like a year or 2 later.  The people who book shows here know up & coming talent.  POPSCENE is great!.I took my 11 year old honor roll daughter here for a sold out Sky Ferreria show (All ages) last year at her begging request.  Don't get me wrong, I'm a super cool dad, and have seen, and done it all, but even I was reluctant to take my child to a late night music venue.Rest assured, we had such an awesome experience together, and every person in the jam packed house was super nice, and were even going out of there way to make sure she was comfortable in viewing.  My daughter felt the vibe fast, and fell in more love with the people of SF, and the regulars at this spot.This was our experience, and I thought it was worth sharing.

Rickshaw Stop is, along with The Independent, one of the top live music venues in San Francisco. While their sound system is not absolutely amazing, it's more than adequate and the space lends itself to some pretty intimate experiences. I shook hands with Penguin Prison before he went onstage and thanked him for playing. I saw an amazing set by Tesla Boy (their first ever in the US) and was about five feet away from the stage the entire time. The Drive Tour was fantastic with Anoraak, College and Electric Youth all playing full-length sets.Rickshaw Stop has already provided me with memories that will last a lifetime and I hope there are many more to come. Definitely check out their regular Popscene nights where you'll be sure to discover a hot new act before they go on to play much bigger (and lamer) venues.

Wanna hear some live music from your favorite indie band? This is the venue.It's a fun location with a GA area downstairs in front of the stage, plus a bar, while upstairs you have another bar and seating for those who don't want to stand/dance.You can have a balcony view upstairs or just chill on the back couches with the band playing in the background.The DJ has a set up on the side downstairs, where you can see the likes of Aaron Axelsen spin during his Popscene nights.Since it's a small venue, you can get up close and personal with the band, especially if they're selling merch at the table near the entrance, where a couch is also situated.The staff is really cool and they have a computerized check-in system if you purchased your tickets ahead of time online.*Tip: Bring your own earplugs, as they don't have any here.*Tip: Coat check is upstairs for $3.*Tip: Arrive when doors open if you want a sweet parking spot right in front of the venue.

Gotta give this place props for great up-and-coming acts and interesting events with good variety. IT's a cool space. The skee-ball is a nice touch (though I keep not playing it, even though I feel like i will each time). It's chill, unpretentious, fun.Comfy-ish seating on the balcony. Drinks are very average, but fine. Snacks are good, approriate. It's an above-average, slightly-better-than-divey place. It's good to look at their calendar once a month or so and see if there's something that piques your interest. If there is, go. You'll be happy you did.
Fun little small area to go to went there for GAMeBoi and had a blast the only thing that was a bummer was parking because it is in downtown n it's hard to find parking around there

The rickshaw is a great place to enjoy a concert. They host lots of great indie bands and each concert is always only like $15. Standing room with a balcony. Really up-close-and personal with the band.The location on fell is a little eerie at night, so bring a friend! Great Place, Recommended

Rickshaw is a good place for dancing and live music. They have a full bar, but I always felt like their drinks were a little overpriced. The women's restroom can be a nightmare. The upstairs is nice with plush seats and games. There is also a bar upstairs. I sometimes enjoy sitting up there when I'm there for a show, but you want to get there early to grab a seat.

I used to love coming here when I was younger. For shows or just to hang out with friends. It has small intimate feel for shows, and good music for non show days. Great place for those under 25 to hang out. There is also a cool 2nd floor, but tables are hard to get, at least the one at the ledge. I usually tend to hang out at the bar downstairs in the back. Gives me a better view and away from the pillars blocking the stage.
Good place for dancing and live music. They have 18 and over nights but you need to call and check or see if they have it posted online.

funnnn venue, it's so cute how the second story also serves as a balcony to look onto the stage down below. On the second floor, you will find couches, chairs, a pool table, and other games/art that just gives this place so much personality. Concerts here are definitely intimate and awesome, so this venue is the perfect size to see your favorite artists when they come tour in SF. Drinks and beer are reasonably priced; I had a delicious glass of sangria that was only $5 and did not make my asian glow appear hahaha!

As my first club, Rickshaw Stop has a special place in my heart. The venue isn't exactly the prettiest place - it looks rather sketchy from the outside actually. Even on the inside, it's rather austere, though the rickshaw is an interesting, nice touch.I cannot comment on the food or the drinks, but as a concert venue, it's amazing. The ground floor is rather large, so it's well-suited for the acoustics. If the show's ever too wild, there is also a second floor viewing deck. Though it may be case by case, when I went, DSLRs was allowed, so as a photographer, that was definitely a plus.I came here to see Boris and Deafheaven, both of which were amazing acts. For groups that had a really powerful sound impact, the venue and setup did them justice. It was an intimate affair, and I much preferred the atmosphere compared to a larger venue.The lighting of this place is also amazing, so props to whoever was manning the lights that night. My pictures turned out well, the atmosphere of the concert was chill, and even the people were very relaxed - much unlike what you may find at a more typical concert.If Rickshaw Stop ever hosts an act I'm interested in, I'll be sure to come back.TIP: DSLR Photography is allowed (or at least at the concert I went to), so feel free to shoot away!
Fun little spot, for a younger crowd, staff is ok, sound is solid.

Here's my tip for you: go for the sangria.  It's the alcohol value ratio by far.  Backing up:  went to the cool Movie Video Race event last weekend and loved being washed over by the hippity-hip-hip-hipsters. Even standing in line was awesome - "hey - I went to a silent disco on twin peaks last night" etc. Damn, the things you learn when you get out a little.  Got inside in time to actually get a spot with our backs to the bar to hold us up as the place filled up....and up.....and up. And we were right next to the free water station so once we were packed in like sardines, we got our body rubs free as people moved past us to get their free H20.Anyway, started with a drink special with tequila because they don't have a stout that sounded interesting. It wasn't so great and definitely teeny, so went for the sangria.  Hallelujah, I hit the motherlode!  $5 and the wine is laced with a hefty portion of brandy, so by the time I was two sangrias in and my friend showed up, I'm sure she didn't recognize my sentences as english.The bartenders were very friendly and the place reminded me a smidge of New Parish, for you Oaktown folk.  I could see the band that played fairly well, and the video screens were high enough up that even the amazonian people in front of us didn't block them too much. Seriously - hubby's 6'2" and there were MASSIVE quantities of people taller than him in front of us. Is this younger generation living longer AND getting taller? Not fair man, not fair.Oh - final stamp of approval for the Boffo cart out front that sold the Yams. Holy sriracha sauce, them puppies are delicious!  And spicy enough that we shamelessly drank someone's open and forgotten bottle of IPA that we watched sitting there on the bar for 20 minutes with no one claiming it.  So there ya go - even got a bonus drink out of it. (Don't judge - you'd have done it too, I swear.)

Richshaw is a great venue- tickets are really cheap, and even at a sold out show there was plenty of space.There is also an upstairs area to hang out with couches so you can listen to the band like a loser not next to the stage in the thick of it.
I rang in the New Year at the Rickshaw Stop to see Turquoise Jeep.Drinks were cheap.Their house DJ is terrible.There is an upstairs area that I didn't visit.

This is one of my favorite venues in San Francisco.  They have good bands that know how to put on a show but haven't blown up so much that there are a lot of jerks in the audience.  I saw how to dress well and sky ferreira last night; all in all a great show.  Sound quality is great though very loud!  Make sure to bring earplugs.  Nerd nite is pretty fun here too; though it gets extremely packed (haven't been in a long time because of that).  Also, efficient, good bartenders who make the drinks nice and strong.

Bought tix on line a couple months in advance for my son and I to see one of his fav bands. I'd never even heard of RICKSHAW STOP..but, it was an all ages event (my son is 16), the location was decent, and the tix were only $12, so I took a chance. We arrived at 8 (posted start time) and waited in a long line outside. My ID was checked. My son was not required to show ID, but the back of his hands were marked with giant X's to signify no ID/underage. Once inside, we began to explore. Upstairs is a cute little room with a foosball table and a classic skee-ball game. Cool! Lots of chairs and couches for chillin upstairs. There are also 2 small tiers of balcony bench seating with a stage view. These spots were taken..so we went back downstairs. The staff was nice, and, although I didn't order a drink, the bar seemed organized and moving along at a good pace. This was a sold-out show (Sky Ferreira, How To Dress Well, and The High Highs) so I was pretty surprised we snagged a spot at the stage. Everyone was respectful..no cursing, drunken fools pushing up against us like at other venues. Sound system was amazing. Speakers took everything the bands could dish out with no distortion. Volume was loud, but not obnoxious. Watching each band set-up and tear-down inches away from us kept the 'down time' interesting. Security didn't trip when I snapped a couple pix (no flash) which was refreshing. The entire place (including restroom) was clean and well maintained. Can't wait to come back to this venue!!

Such a small venue. But if you go when it's super crowded, there's a "sweet spot" house right that gets the best air conditioning. The balcony is also a fun spot to people-watch. Red Stripe is always my best friend when I'm at Rickshaw.

We saw Youngblood Hawke and The Mowgli's here on March 8th. It was a truly great concert experience and one I'm not soon to forget. It is a more intimate venue, which could mean something negative, but it was extremely positive in this case. We were able to get seats up top and watch but then went down closer to the stage to dance and such. Drinks were moderately priced and very strong. Hoping to get back here some day!

This a great small to mid-sized venue to see bands or djs.  Although it's essentially a big box, there's a mezzanine and the sound is great.  I've seen a lot of great shows here and am always pleased to actually be able to meet the bands afterward.

This place is so loud. Tiny. Can get crowded. Hosts a lot of cool indie artists before they blow up. The bathrooms are disgusting and I saw two people drop their drink, thereby getting glass everywhere. Watch where you walk in here. Regardless, I'd probably go back.

Awesome music venue! Most acts aren't "famous" but many of them will definitely get big. Like others have said, it's a great place to catch acts that will be selling out places at 2x the price a year later. The drinks here are pretty strong and the redbull/vodka's come in a pint glass!The balcony is cool and I saw that they have a foosball table in the back. Very limited seating, but who cares when you can be dancing! One negative is that the floor can get VERY smoky, I found it hard to breathe at times.

Came here to see Jukebox the Ghost as part of Noise Pop fest. The upstairs is so much better than the downstairs. We actually found space on the sofas, even though downstairs was packed. Best seat in the house for an observer. Excellent show(s), however there really was something wrong with the sound board/mixer. There was some seriously annoying feedback. Overall though, it was a great show at a rad venue!

Fuck this place. I hardly ever write yelp reviews but when a place sucks enough I feel then need to share with the public. Everywhere on their website and one the performer's website it sited that the show started at 9pm. well its midnight now and their headlining act hasn't even started. Okay I get it. Some super stars don't like to start on time. But 3 hours later? thats a bit much. I got fed up and decided to leave, so I went to close out  my tap. The male bartender scoffed at me and preceded to take 4 other orders before even trying to close my tap. I politely asked the female bartender (while I witnessed him serving 4 other people) to check on it and she gave me some bitchy attitude saying they're busy. I understand you're busy. I fucking work in the service industry and I get that thursday-sunday are your busy nights, but don't give me that 'holier than thou' bartender attitude that you think you're deserving of. Then I went to ask for a refund of my money, since I waited 3 HOURS to see someone play, all I got was attitude.Your venus is OKAY at best with your shitty acoustics. Your bartenders are less than personable. Here's a tip. Hire better bartenders who don't give attitude TO PAYING CUSTOMERS, and don't advertise for a certain time and start 3 hours later

This is such a cool venue. Very intimate, and there is no other place that I would like to go see bands perform at. They have some fairly big name bands come through so checking their lineup is a good thing to do every once in a while.I personally love the upper loft because who doesn't want to see some great musicians perform while you get to hang out on some couches?Also, this was my first experience ordering from a "bar" as I chose to come here to celebrate my 21st birthday. The bartender was pretty helpful at helping me pick out a drink as I did not know what to order.

Great intimate venue for up-and-coming bands.  Saw Jukebox the Ghost plus Matt Pond and two opening bands this weekend, a great show.  Change over between bands was quick and efficient.  Matt Pond complained about some problem with the monitor mix, but it sounded good in the house.Some earlier reviews talk about how hot it was, but that's not true anymore.  They must have heeded earlier complaints and installed an air conditioning system that blasts cold misty air over the stage into the audience.  If anything a little too cold, but better than roasting.The grill upstairs isn't terribly impressive; perhaps they serve food to qualify as a restaurant that can allow entrance to people under 21.  If so, good on them, because clearly some of the crowd wouldn't have qualified otherwise.

So here goes. I'm going to make this short.I love coming here. The prices are awesome, and the people at the door are great. I only have one problem, and it's quite a big problem.When I come here for the performers, there are a great number of photographers that attend as well. I don't know whether they are the performers' photographers or the venue's, but every time I have been at the front they end up jumping and standing right in front of the other concert-goers and I. They love to move their arms around to get every possible angle taken on their cameras, blocking the view of the people who were standing in the front originally, and it's an extreme disappointment for those who have stood in line outside and stood right in front for an hour waiting to see an artist that the photographer could care less about.I have had more than one photographer talk down to my friends and I, and I've even had one elbow me in the face--with no apology--while he was taking pictures at extreme angles.It's very unfortunate for everyone who paid to be there, and one could only hope something could be done about this.

Recently came to Rickshaw Stop for the first time to see CAMPER VAN BEETHOVEN & it was an interesting eveningThis venue is super small & reminds me a lot of Red Devil Lounge.  It's skinny & narrow w/ a teeny upstairsSound was a bit distorted on vocals but instruments were okay - the band kept saying they were getting feedback on their monitors but we couldn't hear itSightlines are practically nonexistent - it's standing room only so you are a prisoner to fate & the short-people karma godsSince the venue was small (& sold out) we were standing literally shoulder to shoulder & there was lots of bumping & getting up close & personal w/ those around you....all thought of getting drinkys were thrown out the door since we knew for sure we'd have lost our place / view & it would have been too big a fight to get anywhere near the barNote to self to pick up drinkys before the show starts & the crowd descends en masse towards the stageI liked the fact the show started nice & early even though it was a Sat night so those of us needing to take Muni home afterwards had plenty of time to catch the last trainBut in thinking about the question of would I come back?  My answer at this point is maybe.....it'd have to be a really, really good band to tempt me.  Didn't hate the place at all but wasn't completely in love w/ it - middle of the road

love it here. never had a problem. it's a lovely venue. super intimate. i've seen Ellie Goulding, Hundred in the Hands, Oh Land, Penguin Prison, K.Flay, Foster the People, Grimes, oOoOO, Icona Pop, many more... it's an awesome place.i've never had a problem here. all of my friends have. issues with the bar, issues with the bouncer. I only had to leave one show early once for one of my friends. but my friends have all gotten pestered and questioned for the "Xs" and "where they went on their hands" amongst other things. i'm 21 now. but even when i wasn't 21, i was still going here. and i was strolling along having a great time and my friends were all getting crap, like when they came out of the bathroom or what they were drinking. weird shit.nevertheless, i have no beef with 'em. i think the venue is super fun and has an interesting little vibe and the age range there (even on all ages nights) is super vast. kinda creates a little diversity of ages.

Over the past 5 years I have seen some spectacular, MINDBLOWING sets at Rickshaw: Charli XCXSchool of Seven BellsShiny Toy Guns The LovemakersDJ Aaron Axelsen (he books a lot of the great shows here as well)A close, intimate view wherever you are standing as the capacity can hold no more than 200 (if that), the sound is on point, the stage low, the drinks are strong, the crowd is never really a douchey gathering, and most shows are under $20. This venue and Bottom of the Hill are where Coachella/Outside Lands type acts play when they are just starting out. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.
Crazy that you have to pay giant srevice charges for tickets here.  $20 show is $8.90 charge per ticket.  otherwise, not a bad joint...

I definitely want to round this up to 4.5 stars. The past two years I've really had a chance to experience a majority of the different venues that SF has to offer for live music. I've been to the Fillmore, Warfield, Billy Graham, Great American Music Halll, Bimbo's, the Independent, Mezzanine, and last night -- RICKSHAW!HANDS DOWN my #1 favorite venue. I am all for intimate venues. This was such a hole in the wall venue and the fact that it was smaller made the event all the more meaningful. No doubt about it, I want Rickshaw to be my go-to spot from now on for live music. I was there to see Jessie Ware and you could tell that each person who was in there was a die-hard fan. Acoustics: TOP notch. The sound of the bass player & drummer were incomparable to anything else. It was literally like I had a private session with them -- that's how good their sound was live. On top of that, you can head upstairs where there's a beautiful balcony that overlooks the stage (perfect view if you're lucky to snag a good spot first), as well as a couch for anyone who wants to chill. My friend and I were posted there during the opening act. Only reason why I'm not giving it 5 stars is because of the heat. I was prepared after reading the Yelp reviews but I was still dying while I was in there. They need some ventilation :) But hey, we were in awe of Jessie's talent so it didn't bug me too much.

I went to shows here on back to back nights.  The first night was to see a pop/dance artist at their Thursday night popscene show.  The second night was to see more of a rock/punk/grunge act.  Both nights were really fun.  The Thursday night show was kind of like a gay dance party and the Friday night show was more like a normal rock show.  The venue is small and you can see well from anywhere.  They don't mind cameras and while most the drinks are pricier than I prefer, there were at least a couple drinks each night that were affordable.  I was able to find street parking nearby as well.
Decent club.Watched the band from the balcony.Neighborhood is sketchy, so was not comfortable parking and leaving the car.

Rickshaw stop would get a five star if it weren't for their seemingly strict age rules. I understand this is at times an all ages venue but this being my second (or third) time going, I was kinda put off by the bouncer and bartender. I know I'm young and I'm Asian but I swear to you my ID is real sir and "did you need something?" doesn't seem polite when walking up to a bar. Other than that, positive reviews for this place cuz of the venue itself.. I love their video playbacks and the second story which is a balcony with couches for more tired and comfy couples. I believe there was more space and seating further back upstairs.. Only thing is, this place gets really packed, based off of the few times I've gone here.....But that's because of the awesome artists that come thru. There inbetween sets music is awesome as well. not so crappy house/electronic music that's more my style and the crowd varies from both young to old. Sound is great too (especially with Tom Krell's voice it was absolute magic)Bottled beers are $4 and there are in and outs only for 21+The shows themselves are fairly inexpensive... Paying only $14 to see How To Dress Well (i'd even pay more just to see him &) ) Overall, nice place.. For the few times I've gone, I've always wondered why I haven't gone more. Hopefully next time I don't get awkwardly started at for looking like a 16 year old :C

Rickshaw Stop is one of the best spots we've played so far.Reason #1? Sound.Reason #2? Sound.Reason #3? Sound!The sound on stage was absolutely superb.Most venues only care what the sound is like for people watching the show, but leave the sound on stage as an afterthought.  Normally it's just a cacophony of all sounds overwhelming each other leaving me guessing what's going on. But not at the Rickshaw, where the sound on stage was amazingly clear.  I could actually hear the guitars, the vocals, and my bass.The stage is great as well.  It's big, with lots of room to move around.  It's not too high or too low, so we have a good view of the crowd and feel like we're right on top of them. And lighting was fantastic as well.  It actually went along with what we were playing, mood-wise and tempo as well.It's a great venue to play a gig at, which in turn makes it a great venue to watch a band as well.  We hope to be back soon!

My first time at the Rickshaw Stop, was a disappointment. I really wanted to see Paloma Faith, love her music, so a friend & I drove two hours to SF for the show.  It was supposed to be my birthday present to him.  I saw three different promotions for the show, they all said 8PM show.  It also said it would open with DJ music, so I guessed Paloma wouldn't start at 8, but hopefully not too late as we had to drive home the two hours so my friend could go to work the next day- but we figured if the show lasted til 11, we could get back home by 1.  Well, we stood in line out in the cold windy sidewalk for an hour, they finally opened the doors at 8:25...some guy kept coming out to look at the line, but wouldn't say when the doors would open.  OK, so we get inside at 8:45, get settled in upstairs and listen to the DJ play Motown 60's, which was great.  By 9:30, my friend is getting stressed about how late the trains run to get back to our car, and after 10 more minutes, said he isn't really in the mood to wait any longer.  The place had filled up long ago and we noticed some people were giving up their seats and leaving (mostly older folks, it was a really mixed crowd.)  It wasn't so much we minded losing out on our $15 admission, but we really wanted to see Paloma perform and felt like the 8pm time was really misleading.  As we left, I asked the doorman when Paloma would actually  play, and he said 10pm.  I guess my biggest gripe was the lack of clarity of the schedule- if I had known the show didn't really start til 10, I wouldn't have bought tickets.  I liked everything else about the Rickshaw, I only wish the venue would be more transparent in their timetable.  It gave me the feeling they wanted people in two hours early to buy more drinks.  Hey Rickshaw, would it really be so hard to say "doors open at eight, showtime at 10?"

The rating is the average for being a club (2 stars) and as a place to see live music (0 stars).As a club it is nothing special, kind grungy and dirty looking. The staff is nice and friendly, so that gets them a couple points.It is a horrible place to see live music. The sound system sucks and everything is distorted. By the time the live act comes on, the majority of the patrons have been drinking for 2 hours. Great for the club scene, not so great for the music scene.Basically if you're a fan of the artist or group, give it a miss, as it is not going to be a good show.

Great selection of shows, especially new/emerging acts, but apparently the actual show times are left to the individual performers. Door advertised as 8pm; 10pm & still no performance. I don't appreciate my time being arbitrarily wasted. Set a f*cking show time & stick to it. Don't waste my time.

You can cry about this being hipster central but whatever -- it's a really fun place to party and that's all I care about. I've seen all types of acts here from Nosaj Thing, to the Matches, to Katy B, to Flosstradamus, and soon Lianne La Havas -- it never disappoints. Great bar service with decent prices. Sound is blasting. The vibe is always really positive. I believe they have coat-check. Always plenty of street parking within a few blocks. Put on your dancing shoes and get ready to get sticky in that motha.

Saw Dillon Francis here twice, once in 2011 and once this past Thursday.- Easy parking (and also close to Bart, I think Civic Center?)- Drinks are large, served in pints and not too expensive. Strong.- Coat check is upstairs, $3- Security is pretty strict.Overall, a lot of fun both times i've been but the crowd gets suuuper packed and pretty rowdy.

God awful venue.And not even the size or that anything was wrong with the venue itself its jus the fucking staff.I saw Dillon Francis and Flosstradamus here and Flosstradamus killed it, Dillon Francis was killing it too and thats the only reason I was able to have fun. But furreal, the staff confiscated my friends prescription medication cuz he thought they were drugs. The staff is rude and stubborn and are fucking bent on strolling around trying to catch people doing anything. You can't go outside to smoke or just get fresh air if your under 21. They kick you out i they see you wash your hands for more than like 10 seconds cuz they think your trying to wash the x off your hands that say you can't drink. They just loooooooooooove to kick people out.But furreal fuck this place. Wouldn't be a bad venue if it had different staff.

I've been here a couple times, and on Friday I saw my second show here (Sharon Van Etten), which was amazing. Granted, they had their own sound engineer, but all the levels were perfect and the songs sounded so crisp--even a bit better than my other favorite little SF venue, Bottom of the Hill. The only drawback to the live show was being stuck behind a bunch of obnoxiously tall people--I wish more small venues like this had sloped flooring for us shorter people. If the opening band sucks (like this one did) see if you can snag the big comfy red couch by the merch table--and if that's full, traverse upstairs for somewhat limited "mezzanine" seating. Apparently there is a smoking room up there, so be aware if you're sensitive to that. They have a good drink selection and have cute specials that are themed after the performers (the "Van Etten" consisted of white champagne grapes and other yummy ingredients). I stuck with an Ace cider. This place is in a weird area, but it sounds like people actually don't have too much of a problem parking around here? I've had my car broken into too many times to trust it around these parts, though.

Great place for live performances! I watched Sharon Van Etten on Friday night (Outside Lands weekend). Besides it being a major plus that they had such a phenomenal artist at their venue, it was a cool spot. There's a second floor with chairs, benches, and couches (early birds get the worm). I tend to get hesitant with public couches, but thankfully I didn't have any issues there. The main floor is also huge. It has a very convenient location, on Fell and Van Ness, with easy access for street parking.

Tips and Tricks:The Big Ole and Big Dickel equate to three drinks anywhere else. Fantastic Deal, makes up for cover, even if it's for a great band at $15.Get there at least 20 minutes early to snag a good couch on the balcony.You can park in the dingy yellow almost-painted spots along the street at night.  (got a spot after someone in front of me starred at it for 30 seconds before going all risk-averse)Beware of anyone who's hands are conveniently covered by long sleeves and asks you to buy their drink. (seriously people, everyone knows that one Oxy pad will take off permanent marker like Mr. Clean Magic Eraser)Don't try and beat my top score on skeeball, you might throw out your shoulder. :-)

So many great acts shimmy through this venue! Get your Indie Rock Pete on and see them here - before the covers they command multiply several times and you have to glue opera glasses onto your wayfarers to see them on the stage.

I came here when they had a berlin table tennis / ping pong event. Summary: Casual clubbing with games and drink specials including special events with a cover.Somewhat big "dance" area with a crazy mix of music, hippies were everywhere!  I like how casual everything was, it really reminded me of a house party.Berlin ping pong - paddles are just laying around, a circle forms around the table, everyone pounds on the table to commence the start of the game, once everyone wanting to play has joined, the 1st player hits the ball and moves to the side, the opposite returns then moves to the side, the players walk around the table hitting the ping pong until they mess up.  Fun, easy, chill, can play while drinking, and awesome way to get to know your "neighbor".  Drink specials - changes all the time2nd floor: has a over view of the entire dance floor, has a rickshaw, skeet ball, and foosball (1 of the guys is missing feet), sofas, and chairs. LOVE everything about this.The atmosphere is very laid back, and if hippies are your thing, you'll love this place.  Not sure if its every day, but for this event, there was a $5 cover.

I came here for Nerd Nite, which was totally five stars.The venue, on the other had... not so much.  By the time it was declared "sold out" most of the bar had turned into standing room only.  Also, the beer was $6/pint.  Too crowded and too pricey for my taste.The crowd and the staff were all nice people, at least.
It was my first time there to check out Copperwire feat Meklit Hadero, they rocked the joint. Solid selection of beer...

This place is a little grimy, but they host the most fierce, competitive, and traditional sport in America. It mixes the athleticism of running, the hand-eye coordination of drinking, and the fun of inebriation. I went there for the Berlin style ping pong. It was a blast. It's coming up again and they're bringing another table along with foosball and skeeball. The drinks were pretty cheap. I feel like I can never gauge how much a drink is going to cost me in this city based on the decor of the place. But the prices match the setting which is nice because I'm poor and I usually have to slip in with a flask. Not so much here.The crowd is very mixed and get ready for hipster watching, and the occasional older ladies joining in on the fun.

Apparently, musicians love playing here, and I can understand why: *The sound is really superb with strategically soft surfaces to smooth out the acoustics. The ceiling is so thoroughly draped, you'll want to sleep on it. *The space feels intimate but not claustrophobically so, with a large open downstairs and a secluded upstairs lounge that offers an ideal view of the stage and comfy seating. It's SO worth getting there early to snag one of these primo spots. *Full bar, with cute little cans of Sofia sparkling wine to sip from a straw! I like my beer straight out the bottle, and my champagne straight out the can.*Good flow between the three key areas: bar, bathroom, stage. It feels clean, not pristine; and hip, with just a hint of hipster. Overall, a great place to be entertained by some stellar local acts (Sea of Bees...I heart you so much...will you autograph my bra strap, pleeeeeease?!?)

I'm updating my initial review (below) bc I've been back a few times and it's kind of hit or miss with the crowd. It is an 18 and up venue, which is a minus in my mind, but of course that's good if you're 18-20.... I like how the space has two levels, the drinks are strong, and they get good shows. Not the best venue I've been to, but it's usually a good time. Just be prepared to get (or throw) some elbows if you're concerned about your space.Initial thoughts: what a frickin mess. unless you are 18-20, i suggest staying away. idiots were pushing through all over the place, as if mommy & daddy had just let them out of the house. this place screams all-ages club filled with kids who don't know how to hold their liquor. not at all my scene, but at least i had fun dancing.

After paying $10 to get in the door, the tiny $3 coat check was full! Go to Ikea and get a friggen rack.  I wanted to shake it and get down on the dance floor but was forced to carry lbs of jacket.  No, I will not leave my nice things unattended or hide them under your sofa and over 5 years of accumulated vomit stains.  For what it is, an open gymnasium with pretty great dance music, it had a large crowd and some good quality folks.  I just wish I could have enjoyed my experience without having to sweat so much.
I've been here twice:Once for Cockblock with a dear bunch of friends who put the 'L' in LGBTQAS.Once for Leslie & the LY's.Both were occasions for a lifetime.
This place is awesome but the booking agent here doesn't know how to do business. Emailed Dan a few times and he's not good at replying at all.

After suffering through a douchebag NYE at Ana Mandara last year, I took the bull by the horns and suggested we go to Rickshaw for this year's outing.  Thank god!First of all, it was only $35 (at the time we bought tickets about 2 weeks in advance) and included a live show by the Limosines and and awesome dance party courtesy of some Popscene DJs from Portland who were amazing!  I like that they didn't ovesell the event.  There was actually room to dance and move around.This is a hipster paradise and I love it.  Saw some incredible creative and beautiful outfits that night!  People may hate on hipsters but let's be honest, they can drink and aren't afraid to wear face paint.  I'll take that over striped shirts, cuff links and black pleather dress shoes any day!
I have countless memories at this venue and will always have a place in my heart.

I would give this place negative stars If I can. The woman bar tender is a bitch. Seriously. She crapped on my whole experience.  Ugh!My friend ordered jack and coke and I ordered coke. She had poured only jack in the first glass and I said oh sorry, I want my coke without ice. She goes everybody orders with ice generally. I am like i know. Sorry. But she did not pour my coke without ice! She was not finished making the first drink yet when i corrected my order! And ofcourse has not charged anything. I was so shocked with her rudeness that I just accepted it. Now I am pissed. oh and coke was $4! The reason I am so pissed is that she went out of her way to be rude.  It's one thing if she already had poured the coke in the glass with ice and had to waste that coke to give me correct order.  I would totally understand. Even though most of the people would make a new drink to make customer happy. So in the end I paid $20 cover and four times the actual price of coke just to be greeted in such a "nice" way. Feels really good.About the music and actual club, it's ok i guess.  Nothing special, If anything the space is really small. Certainly the rude welcoming experience did not help their cause.

UMMMMM....  :XOk, honesty is the best policy right? Rickshaw Stop is just NOT my scene. I didn't even know this place existed much less was located 1.5 blocks from the office. In theory, it would be the perfect spot to Party Like A Rockstar then crawl underneath my desk, wake up the next morning, and hope no one remembers what I wore the previous day. Ok, maybe not because I'm a lady after all.Rickshaw Stop is a club that has live band performances specifically Indie music. They also have Bhangra nights which is some sort of Indian folk dancing.  When we ended up here last night (not by choice) for a Popscene party, I pretty much sobered up after seeing shirtless men doing interpretive dances. A guy next to us then started throwing up all over himself while no one even seemed to care. That pretty much sealed the deal for me.  Now that I got that out of the way, I'll keep this to a venue only review. COVER$15-$20 (Depending on the performers, tickets can be bought online fro $5-$15)DRESS CODENoneCROWDVery mixed but mainly hippies and hipsters.MUSICIndie. I don't even know what this is so not even going to elaborate on this. BAR2 barsDRINKS$9-$10 for top shelf liquor. $20 minimum for CC'sAMBIANCE/DÉCORSmall, grey, and sweaty. Huge ceiling-to-floor red curtains added a splash of color along with the tv projection scene playing psychedelic images. The main level has the dance floor and stage. The upper balcony level has a couches, food bar, and a smoking lounge. There were also two rickshaw carts which I really wanted to crawl into to sleep but it probably would have broken into pieces. PARKINGPlenty of street parking. Beware of street cleaning though so make sure to check the signs. That is all...P.S. - This is a generous 3 STAR review because security aren't douchebags which most SF clubs employ.

Unlike some venues in SF (ahem Slims), Rickshaw has a lot of personality. Located nearby to the deco ghetto, this place is definitely a destination of its own. It's a good medium sized venue, has great lighting and atmosphere with the curtains along the walls, and I like that it has an upstairs. This is key, because sometimes you just want to hang back and watch a band from slightly afar. Only downside is that the draft is almost always warm.

Ahh I love this place .... !I just recently have been turned on to this place by a friend .. We usually show up to Pop Scene on Thursday for some good dancing fun ... Always a blast ...The space is great ... walk in bar to the right that leads to a big dance floor with a stage up at front ... There is a balcony over head that I believe has a bar and more seating as well ... And of course there are random rickshaws scattered about ... The music scene is full of variety .. I been to Dj shows, Rave type shows, Indie Shows, and etc ... It's refreshing and Just feels great to dance thursday night away .. Good stress relief .My advice is show up and just dance the night away .. and hey if you go Thursday maybe i'll see yah :)
I liked the environment and the people ! Very diverse crowed !!! However bartenders weren't too friendly :/

Only been here for Popscene parties. Good music and cheap price for concerts!Alcohol is watered down BOTH TIMES I was here. I only buy bottle beer now. Kegs are not that fresh either, well the Sierra wasn't...

I'm really surprised by the overall rating this place has. I've only been here once but I truly feel that the rating for this place is way overblown. I went here back in July for a concert during the week. Everything as far as the staff, bartenders, and overall atmosphere were really nice. I especially liked the upstairs chill area - a nice place to go to get away from the bottleneck that is the entry way. Now for the bad. First off, this place was RIDICULOUSLY HOT INSIDE. It was retarded... no AC, and although they have tons of fans on the ceilings, they wouldn't turn any of them on. I've been to countless overpacked venues and this place was stupidly hot beyond all others. Secondly, the sound system SUCKS hard. sucks so hard that it's just laughable. What's with the arrogant DJ not turning down the sound for a second so the band can do a decent sound check? The band had to ask multiple times and the dude would NOT turn it down. They had to just start the show without going through a full sound check... which probably let to the multiple problems with the sound throughout the show. The tremble would knock out the speaker ever so often and the speakers would constantly crackle from the vocalist. It was sad.thankfully the tickets were super cheap, but that doesn't take away from the fact that this place blows.
Small and sweaty just the way I like it.  Well not too small, but a really cool spot.  Bhangra night was so joyous.

I've been the Rickshaw stop a bunch of times now so I think it deserves a review.  This is a great venue.  The staff is friendly and relaxed, the ambience is great, and the shows are darn cheap!If you are looking for a cheap show and you don't care who the band is, then do I have the place for you.  Generally the most expensive show they have will cost around 12 dollars, no service charge at the door.  The stage is a bit small, but the venue is a bit small.  You can get as close as you want because the floor is pretty big.  I saw Miniature tigers and Neon Indian here and that was the most packed its ever been.  So no worries about sweaty drunks shoving their elbows into you.  There are about three rickshaws around the place that you can sit on, along with more comfortable furnishings.  There are plenty of couches and chairs upstairs for people to sit on, but they get snatched up quick.  I do wish they had some more seating up stairs for this reason.  It is nice to watch the show from a comfy green couch or stare out over the crowd. They have Bhangra Dancing once or twice a month, but I have not been yet.  The shows they have here are generally pretty small, indie bands, so don't expect a huge crowd to show up.  The drinks are pretty varied and well priced.  (Jack and Coke $6)Parking is on the street, but i've never had a problem with it.  This is a great venue.  I've loved it from the big shows to the small.  They bring in great bands and you don't have to spend your whole wallet.  So pull up a couch, buy a drink, and enjoy a show at the Rickshaw.
I come here for the Bhangra nights they throw on a Saturday. While I do like a good dose of bhangra, I'm hoping future DJs throw in some hip-hop as well - just like Punjabi weddings.

We came here after Nightlife to see Skylar Grey.  She was AMAZING.  I'd give her 5 stars!  Rickshaw Stop, on the other hand, is just alright.  I think they water down their drinks, but it was a nice space for seeing Skylar Grey perform.  I'd come back if someone else interesting were performing.Didn't stay for the dance party though, since it was a work night . . .  Not sure how fun it would be since TONS of people left with us after Skylar finished performing.

So, I had a blast at Rickshaw Stop.I went on a Friday night and it happened to be Bardot night. Swingin 1960s French music with Brigitte Bardot playing in the background and balloons floating around. Fabulous! Rickshaw has a huge dance floor and upstairs seating area with a balcony. Service at the bar is good, drinks are reasonably priced and everyone seems down to party. But it gets hot and you will get sweaty. Like, your clothing will stick to your body, your hair will frizz and you will walk outside looking like a complete disaster.But it's fun if you are in the mood to get down with you bad self.

Rickshaw Stop has so many elements going for it to make it a fun night spot but somehow the overall experience comes up just short. It's a nicely-sized club that feels intimate with easy access to the bar where responsive bartenders pour you reasonably priced drinks. The dance floor is reasonably roomy and the lights are pretty awesome. Here's the thing that is a little odd for me though - folks on the dance floor seemed more intent on "posing" versus just dancing and having a good time. Very strange. Still I liked the music and had a good time with my friends. Not my favorite spot to spend the night but I won't be opposed to going back to Rickshaw Stop with the right folks.
I only come here for Popscene. Music is Good.If you get hungry, you can purchase food here to munch on.

This is one of my favorite venues in SF! I have seen so many great shows there. I like it because it is small and the stage is low to the ground, so the band is closer to the crowd. It's also fun to head up to the balcony and see the show from there. Tickets are always affordable and they book great bands. Sometimes if they sell out they'll release a limited number of tickets at the door. It's always a great crowd - I love this place!

I love this venue!  They have a great variety of music and entertainment - everything from the science spectacle of Nerd Nite to the homolicious dance party Cockblock.The staff are laid back and fun while still being on it.  I especially like that they make a drink special for the band that's playing that night.If you go upstairs, you'll find a skeeball machine that even has instructions on how to up your game.  Pow.

This is one of those hole in the wall venues, where if the door isn't open you wouldn't even know it's there. The is no sign, its almost like a speakeasy, i half expected to be asked for "the password" it's just that cool lol. The place it self isn't anything special. But theres a small bar, they have good music, and a good sound system. Not much more you can expect these days from music venues.

Pretty cool venue, they've got a pretty chill upstairs area with a bar, my only complaint would be that when I was underage I would get upset that a number of their shows were either 18+ or 21+. But overall a cool venue

An intimate-type venue where you get a chance to mingle with the performers. I love how it's a block and a half away from the Van Ness Muni station, extremely convenient. The couch in the back is super comfy by the way.I came here last night with my sister and her boyfriend to see Sleigh Bells, Neon Indian, and Rosco Delrey. They were all amazing!I love how the stage is almost at ground level, but, it sucks being in the front when everyone behind you is going nuts. Prepare to get cuts and/or bruises on your thighs.

Not a smoker, but yes they've got an INDOOR smoking room on the second floor.  Most recently went for the Limousines show (but they have also had a distracting amount of good acts and parties to frequent) and loved that (got the set list!) but also the special cocktail of the night, which they switch up all the time.

this place is so much fun! the sound is good here and on Thursday nights for "popscene" they have amazing DJs and bands. drinks are priced well and the bathroom is pretty good. there is seating on the upper level.this is my favorite spot in sf i would definitely check this place out!

Where the F is the box office, oh, the isnt one. What!?!?! you dont take credit cards?!?!? well, thank god i brought a 20!came here alone (pathethic i know) to see Lenka and Greg Laswell.Sat upstairs in the corner. Could see and hear everything fabulously. The lights hung on the ceiling are cute.I feel like they probably have highschool dances here or something, its got that vibe.Smelled a little like cigg smoke, but i didnt see anyone smoking,,,, did the smell come in from outside? no idea.
Friendly staff, but illegal smoking upstairs stinks.  There is a "game room" where patrons smoke inside.  There is no ventilation so upstairs reeks of tobacco.

I came here for the first time to see Memoryhouse, with no expectations. It had been a hectic few weeks, and I felt like when I went in to The Rickshaw Stop, all of a sudden everything mellowed out. The atmosphere was both calm and friendly. The red curtains gave the place such a nice feeling. Everyone seemed in good cheer and sharing that energy with everyone else, which was something I hadn't felt much since moving to California. The upstairs was pretty cool too, with the bike and the couches. The bar served reasonably priced and creative drinks (the special is always themed with the evening's features.) One of the staff asked me for my I.D. because I fit the description of someone who had apparently stolen someone else's purse, and then, unlike in most situations, when I tried to inquire and help, instead of being a jerk, he was cooperative and instead of what could have been a terrible experience, it was a pleasant exchange, and i made sure to let him know that and thank him for handling the situation so well.I came back for a bunch more shows, all of which were also satisfactory and beeming with good vibes.Lastly, I was so elated to find that Nerd Nite not only exists outside of Boston, but is so well attended in San Francisco!I loved living right across the street from the Rickshaw Stop for the brief time that i got to do so. I miss being able to cross the street to see a great show, enjoy myself without worrying, and then cross the street again and go to bed at a decent hour.

It might have been because Rickshaw was spacious and I had the ability to walk around without bumping into anyone or the fact that all 5'1" of me got to stand on a table so I could get an unobstructed view of the headliner (something I'm not used to at all), but I'm a fan of this place!  It's got a backyard patio feel to it with the lights hung on the ceiling and an upstairs balcony with adequate seating if you don't want to deal with the mosh pit that downstairs will eventually become.My only gripe about it was that it got very stuffy and hazey.  But I guess that's to be expected when everyone's jumping up and down, dancing.  Overall, a good time!

I went here for strfckr and it wasn't so bad. When you first walk inside, it kind of reminds me of what an 8th grade dance would look like. Cheesy red curtains on the sides with lights hung across the ceiling and wooden floors. Upstairs there's sofas and couches for ppl to sit on and chill and a small smoking area. They seriously do have bad ventilation, it was so freaking smokey/foggy in there. But honestly, just because a venue is so-so isn't really going to stop anyone from coming to see their favorite band. Its no staples center but it still kind of has this cozy feel to it. From the outside, you can't even really tell it's a music venue or that its a really long building but it is!Some annoying things were a bunch of hs hipsters with their huge ass fake glasses and beanies with plaid or ripped shirts always seem to be smoking while waiting in line- i guess to pass the time. Its kind of a weird mix in there because there's barely legal high schoolers to ppl who look like they're fifty. eclectic group of ppl i guess.but I would come here again because it is really fun!

The Rickshaw Stop is my third favorite venue in San Francisco after BOTH and GAMH. Even the lame acts seem better, more personal, and more connected in this spot. The upstairs is chill, the drinks are reasonably priced, and the crowd is always awesome.

It seems to me that reviewing a venue is more like reviewing the time you had or the show you saw unless there was some horrible experience with the staff.  So.  Because I had a really good time seeing No Age here the other night, I'm giving it 4 stars.  There was a mosh pit, where a crowd surfer came about two inches from landing on my head, a young man who more or less head-butted me, and a head banging chick who kept violently running into me as she could not see through her mass of Cousin It-like hair.  The stage was only raised by about two feet, as evidenced from the two baseball sized bruises on my knees from being pushed into the stage by never ceasing, pounding waves of human bodies.  Needless to say, despite the near concussion and other injuries, it was a great time.Also helpful: I found the bartender to have supernatural hearing, an admirable quality when attempting to shout my drink order mid-song.  I couldn't even hear myself, but somehow, amazingly, he was able to ascertain the drink order and get the requested alcohol into my hand.  Amen.

Ahhhh high schoolers making out all around me. I did not expect that, and it was incredibly annoying. It also made me feel old and lame - when did I become such an uptight adult?However, fleeing that scene led me to find the skeeball upstairs, which was pretty rad.  And even on the balcony you have a decent view of the performance and the noise level is perfect if you want to listen to the music while also being able to hold a conversation.So if you can deal with underage kids and like a laid back environment, this place may be for you.  Just don't forget your skinny jeans, ironic t-shirt and plaid. Not sure if they'll let you through the doors without those. ;)

I went here with a couple of friends to watch happy body slow brain's gig. The place was packed. I love the awesome crowd, mellowed down by booze and sangria.The band also featured 3 other artists: Please Do Not FightBird By BirdThe Girlfriend SeasonThe place is a small loft, with a dim-lit stage, a few tables and chairs, pretty much it was a "standing room" which was spacey enough for the swaying crowd. The bartenders were nice and their drink mixes were incredible. I like how accessible it is for commuters like me and it was easy to find. It was worth the walk from the MUNI/BART station, that night. The slow brain punch made my night! smooth!I'll definitely come back for more indie group bands! oh lala! :)

I went here for an event "Nerd Nite", and it was pretty cool.  I really liked the idea of people hanging out and listening to science put in a fun and creative way, like Zombie brains, where a necro-neurologist discussed real brain atrophies that could contribute to the Zombie brain, if existed.  I am a scientist myself, so I might be sort of biased. The atmosphere of this bike messenger hang-out is pretty cool, with a balcony looking onto the stage, and a Skeeball machine in the back. The bartenders were really nice and receptive.   I plan to come back and see a live show sometime.  Parking was really easy, or I got lucky. Cash only, but they have an ATM.

This place is great! I love that there is ins and outs and easy parking. It's also close to BART. There's diverse events here too. The upstairs is chill. I LOVE the free Foosball table! I have played many games with friends and new found friends. There is also plenty of seating upstairs including ones where you can still see the stage. I don't like the smoking room upstairs, considering there's ins and outs anyhow, but I think it's convenient for smokers. However, there is now a SKEEBALL machine inside!! If you break 200 pts, you win a free drink! I also like the 2 rickshaws they have as decor! They make for fun, drunk photo opps. The sound system is decent and the red curtains on stage and around the venue are nice. The drinks are average priced and the staff are nice. The venue is large enough to have an epic dance party, yet still feels intimate. It's a great place to catch or show or dance your pants off.

Came here not too long ago for a private event. It was pretty okay! Nice big venue.One downer: I checked on the website to see if there was a coat check before going. I happily saw that there was indeed a coat check! Then, when we get there, I come to find there is no coat check. If I had known there was no coat check, I would have brought a different (smaller) bag and coat. It was a total bummer trying to keep track of my coat all night.I liked the rickshaws all around! They were fun to sit upon. I'm surprised people don't break them.
Small venue. Upstairs had like a smoking room (yucky suffocating) Came here back in January/Febuary of 2008 with a former roomie & her new friend.

Went last night for the first time to see Moneypenny rock the Rickshaw Stop's fucking face off, and from the moment I came to the door, the guy taking ID's (who I believe was also part of security, but he was totally skinny and non-threatening, so I only imagine he possessed insane kung fu skills) was cool as hell.  I was amazed at the amount of close parking for a Friday night as well.  Lot's of really cute chicks, many single, some a little too wasted, friendly bartenders (when it was time to sober up and stop drinking, they gave me free Cokes), and just a really laid back, chill crowd. Only negative was the jackass who was so drunk he could hardly piss in the urinal.  I actually stood behind and to the side, as I was not in the mood to be saturated in urine.  It was like when you take a diaper off a baby and they piss all over the place.   Aside from that, I will definitely be coming back.  Popscene moving there in January only makes this place better.

Pretty decent venue. Space is intimate, sound carries well. Coat check upstairs. Smoking room has foosball and skee ball. I didn't go in, but I eyed the smokers with envy as I'm a sucker for skeeball. Well, maybe it wasn't even skeeball.. I don't know. Looked like it from the outside looking in.If you like to sit, like I do, then head upstairs. No seating on the main floor.Upstairs has two levels. Both with various seats. My man and I snagged a love seat couch and yea, we made out. It was fun watching couples cram into rickshaw seats. If you want to ensure that you can actually SEE the band/stage then make sure you are on the lower of the two upper levels and bellied up to the rail. Because as we found last night (Freelance Whales and Miniature Tigers, vg btw) when the main acts come on stage people will come stand between you and the rail thereby blocking your view if you are seated. Upstairs bar has no tap and only bottled beers/Bathrooms were nasty! But that's normal in these venues.Crowd was very young. Lots of high school kids with back packs. Upon entry I joked with the bouncer that we (me and my main squeeze) would probably be the grandpa and grandma in the club. He took one look at my ID and said "I think you already win that award by a long shot". I would like to note that I saw at least 3 men in their 60's here. So we did not win that prize. There were also dads chaperoning their underage kids. That was funny, watching the kids ignore their dad as dad tried to engage said children in conversations.As far as local venues to see up and coming acts in a small setting. This one was pretty good. I'd go back, grandma status aside.

Came here the other night to watch Toro y moi and Nosaj Thing. As a music venue, it's pretty big compared to some other ones I've been too in the city, but maybe it was because I was upstairs in the balcony area the whole time.  -1 star - for the smoking area. There is no ventilation whatsoever in the little 10x10 room. -1 star - for all the youngsters. Overall, it was a good show. If there was another good performer coming, I wouldn't mind coming again.

2.5 stars, really.I proceeded with caution after reading other reviews. I didn't want to get vomit on my shoes or some unidentifiable stain on my clothes... so I mainly stayed toward the back lol. Regardless, I think my experience was a bit different, because I went for a CD release rather than to dance.This place definitely is a hipster haven. It's bigger than a lot of the other venues I've been to, and it's really hard to see the stage from the back. There were a bunch of drunk people dancing around the back and congregating around the bar, and this older man grabbed my ass. Awkward. Honestly, I think next time I'm going to a show, I think I'll stick with places like Bottom of the Hill or Slim's.

I saw Aloe Blacc here last night, and I thought it was a great venue.  (Great show, too!)  The size of the place is good, and the bar was run efficiently, which is always a plus.  I'm a fan of the self-serve water on the end of the bar.  Easy access to water is a good thing.

I'm reviewing Rickshaw Stop as a music venue, not a dance club or bar.  I have no idea what it's like as a club, but from some of the pictures posted, it looks like a lot of drunkies dancing with brightly colored beverages.As a music venue, I've enjoyed Rickshaw overall.  The place certainly has personality including random rickshaws placed around the space.  The bar is conveniently located on the side and is cheap.  The venue itself is a good size with a smaller balcony in the back for people trying to avoid the standing room crowd.My only complaint about the venue is the crowd sometimes errs toward the young'uns side, which can make me feel like an old creepy dude scouting.  Once I went to a show where the opening band was clearly from the local high school as the front of the room became heavily populated with kids with backpacks.  They began moshing to music that probably shouldn't be moshed to.Another time, I went to watch a Wavves show and a young man jumped on stage and started dancing like a chimpanzee on crack.  He tried to fend off a bouncer who was about 3x his size and ended up getting choke slammed off the stage.  Definitely worth the price of admission.

Meh. Definitely for the hipsters. Pretentiousness is on full blast so beware. Most of the get ups are straight out of Us' "What Were They Thinking" page. Plus, I've been disappointed too many times by the music. I was expecting mash ups and other fun, dancey tunes, but the DJ never delivered. Won't be back.

this was my friends and i spot freshman year of college. i remember having a blast here! have not been in a while but i remember good times. dancing on stage, smoke room, indian dancers, trying to get drinks under 21 haha

Second time I've caught a show at the Rickshaw and overall, I love this place. Has some definite drawbacks but not enough to ever prevent me from going to a show. Bar service is fast considering the setup is not ideal as it's in between the main floor and the bathrooms. Congestion happens but they seem to turn over customers rather quick. Smoking room upstairs can get pretty stinky and humid but they allow you to go in and out if you're over 21 for air. Major drawback is the lack of ventilation. Both shows I've seen turned into a yoga hotbox fart factory from hell. Main door in front is the only source of air, time to upgrade your systems yo.
Blow-up! I actually had fun going to that club. Drink and DANCE! I kinda miss going to this club since I move-on to a different club when I turned 21.

I come here for Nerd-Nite, which is always packed with nowhere near enough seatings for anybody. The drinks are a bit pricy. The place is a convention oven though, it gets so blazingly hot in here that it's too much. The Nerd Nite's are completely different variety and quality. The World Beard Champion was great but the talk about sex education wasn't that fascinating or funny, though educational.
I miss Blow Up SF! Haven't been back since they stopped having it.
Fun eclectic bands at affordabel prices! Good Accoustics, Great Bar staff always a good time!

This place is great, both for concerts and DANCE PARTIESSSSS.Oops too excited.  But really...I came here with some friends for cockblock, and left with sore legs and a boosted ego.  Here's how it went down:We got to the club, went through easily.  The girl at the door was really nice (she later on came to us when we were taking a break outside and offered us gummies!).Inside, the music was pretty good.  I danced crazily because I figured, well, no one's gonna look at me anyway - it's a lesbian night after all.  But, lo and behold, a girl across the stage points to me and gestures for me to go over...First thought: "It's a lesbian night!  What could she want from me?"Second thought: "Does she think I'm a lesbian!?"Third thought: "I REFUSE TO BE JUSTIN BIEBER."Anyway I go over and turns out it's her girl friend who's interested (read: drunk).  I politely interact with her (read: avoid being vomited on) to try and see if maybe she thought I was a lesbian, but alas, she did not.  Oh well, mission look-like-a-lesbian unaccomplished, but mission dance-your-ass-off?  Check.

First and last experience at this venue tonight is sadly something that I won't soon forget.  Not only was I dismayed to find the cover at the door for the night was 50% higher than was advertised on their website, but the night got worse from there.I was invited by some friends to come out and see/hear this apparently great DJ, but when I got there the club was nearly empty, but my friends were there, and I guess that's what really matters.  I had one drink and then switched to consuming little plastic cups of tap-water.  I hadn't been at the club much more than a half an hour when I decided to go outside to check the BART schedule on my smartphone (due to crappy reception in the club).  I carried an almost empty little plastic cup of tap-water with me to the door.  The bouncer, or at least this very non-official-looking skinny guy by the door informed me that I couldn't take my drink outside.  "It's okay, it's just water", I said.  "You can't take alcohol outside.  There's an open container law", he replied.  "No, it's just water", I said again, thinking he hadn't heard me, and I attempted to walk past him.  Suddenly, he swiped the cup from my hand so violently that it tore in half and he started shoving me.  Of course, at this point I began to protest, yelling "What the h*ll", and insisting that I was only carrying water.  The 'bouncer' escalated his violence in turn, yelling and shoving.  He was quickly joined by a short young woman (who I believe was the one who had collected my exorbitant cover charge) in the yelling.  The 'bouncer' demanded that I leave and threatened to call the police.  I freely admit to yelling and hurling a few expletives at these two, but at no time did I do anything improper or touch either of them.  I demanded that they "get out of my face", but the shoving and cursing from them just continued.  Suddenly, they were joined by a third small young man in the yelling match.  I demanded several times to know who all these people were.  Only the small man answered me, claiming to be the club owner.  I was shocked by this, as he was clearly much younger than I.  He appeared to be not far from college age.  The yelling and shoving continued, yet at no time did I raise a hand to any of these three, despite my outrage.  I haven't been in a fist-fight since middle school, and I certainly wasn't about to stoop to that level again.  Finally, I turned and walked away.  I suppose the entire altercation couldn't have lasted more than one or two minutes.In conclusion, you should not give these aggressive a**holes any of your hard earned money.  The owners and employees of this club are the dregs of humanity and should be avoided at all cost.  Please find somewhere else to hear music and buy a drink with your friends.

i hav been wanting to see something here. finally i went through and saw the Mynabirds.this was an early concert, we were out at 830pm. but the place was real stuffy upstairs, and i can see the walls sweating when it's at capacity (which can be good or bad depending on who you are seeing).

Because there is no signage suggesting the Rickshaw Stop's existence, I felt especially cool when I found it on a lonely block beneath a black awning. Grand Archives was playing; my boyfriend explained to me that when former band Carissa's Wierd (sic) broke up, some of those members formed Grand Archives, while others formed Band of Horses. So that new knowledge helped me appreciate the night's cleverly named drink special: Clarissa's Wired, containing gin, Grand Marnier, grenadine and lemon. I sipped it while exploring the upstairs seating area, envying the people who scored a spot on a bench with a snake face carved into one end.We took ownership over a wooden structure to the left of the high-up stage on the main level. When I leaned back far enough into the lush, red curtain, I was relieved to discover a wall. Usually when I have a few drinks, I don't act stupid or anything--I just become uncontrollably tired. Thus, after one Clarissa's Wired and two sangrias, I passed out on the wooden structure. My head rolled  around throughout the show because I wanted to stay awake so badly, attempting to nod my head and stomp my feet. But alas, my Clarissa's cocktail left me anything but wired.

Let me say that I have been to many music venues the size of the Rickshaw, and the Rickshaw is definitely one of my favorites, mostly because of the vibe. It's laid back and not too full of itself, or full of unnecessary security, or inflated ticket prices.They have a bar in the back of the main floor, which I prefer to the side bar layout of the Fillmore, mostly because the traffic to/from will walk next to you going forward/back instead of constantly in front of you going side to side. The drinks aren't great, but they aren't high-priced either.Upstairs is a small balcony and a bunch of hipster-style victorian furniture. When we've gone it hasn't been so crowded downstairs that you really wished for a place to escape, but the couches do still provide a great respite from standing and getting bumped. All in all, you can go here and enjoy a show without the annoying crowd factors you get at some other places.

The warm packed nights at Rickshaw stop have scared me off checking out Rickshaw Stop for intimate concerts for awhile now. I'm glad I finally decided to give Rickshaw Stop another chance - cause if you do it right - it's definitely what's up.All you gotta do - is show up early. Make a mad dash to the top floor. Find a big padded soft couch right by the balcony railing. Plop down. Kick back.  Take off shoes. And don't move for the entire night. Unless you have someone to save your spot for you.Where else in the city can you relax and lie down on a soft lovely couch, with a killer view of the stage, while listening to seriously on point music?huh?Trust.

2 1/2 stars.  Decent enough, but by no means exceptional.  The stage is hard to see if you're standing anywhere near the back; other venues in SF seem to be set up better--e.g., the stage is higher, or the floor is slightly angled.  The upstairs seating/standing area was nicer, but tiny.  And the bartenders were kind of rude and served tiny, weak, very expensive drinks.  The whole place was hot and stuffy, as other reviewers have mentioned.  I'd only come back if I was pretty excited about whoever was playing (in this case, Junip and Jose Gonzales--good show).

Great venue for show. I have had some great times here. I would love it there was a Rickshaw down here in these parts of So Cal but then I guess going to the Rickshaw when in the City would lose its charm. Love the bi-level atmosphere, when venues do this it always earns points with me, that way I don't feel cramped up and can get away to a different spot.  I am not familiar at all with the dance nights that most people review about just only about seeing live bands. So I say if a friend hits you up to check out their band then I say go, you will probably have a decent time.
Great small venue whether you're playing or seeing a show there. Awesome sound, good bar, friendly staff. They treat bands very well. It's always a pleasure to play there. Hi Waldo!
